title: Expansion microscopy reveals neural circuit organization in genetic animal models
authors: Shakila Behzadi, Jacquelin Ho, Zainab Tanvir, Gal Haspel, Limor Freifeld, Kristen E. Severi
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the major steps of ExM, including anchoring, gelation, digestion, and expansion, highlighting the method's ability to surpass the diffraction limit. Fig 2: Illustrates various ExM protocols, such as proExM and iExM, emphasizing their application in different organisms and tissues. Fig 3: Shows ExM's application in zebrafish, resolving synaptic connections and protein organization, crucial for understanding neural circuits. Fig 4: Highlights ExM's use in mice, revealing deep brain structures and enabling spatial transcriptomics. Fig 5: Depicts ExM's role in Drosophila, allowing high-resolution imaging of entire brains and synaptic structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of previously unresolvable subcellular and nano-structures associated with synapses and neuronal processes, enhancing the understanding of neural circuits across various model organisms.
novelty: This work advances ExM by achieving higher expansion factors and resolution, allowing for the detailed study of neural circuits in genetic models. Compared to prior ExM variants, this study demonstrates the ability to resolve fine synaptic structures and interactions between neurons and glia. The introduction of new chemistry, such as DMAA, and the optimization of gelation conditions, provide significant improvements in resolution and sample compatibility.

title: Light-sheet fluorescence expansion microscopy: fast mapping of neural circuits at super resolution
authors: Jana Bürgers, Irina Pavlova, Juan E. Rodriguez-Gatica, Christian Henneberger, Marc Oeller, Jan A. Ruland, Jan P. Siebrasse, Ulrich Kubitscheck, Martin K. Schwarz
summary: Fig 1: High-resolution confocal microscopy was used to image EGFP-labeled granule cells, revealing limitations in speed and resolution. Fig 2: Light-sheet fluorescence expansion microscopy (LSFEM) was applied to expanded mouse brain slices, achieving high-resolution imaging of granule cells and dendrites. Fig 3: Contrast comparison between Airyscan and LSFEM images demonstrated improved resolution with LSFEM. Fig 4: Sparse labeling allowed tracing of dendritic networks over extended distances. Fig 5: Multicolor imaging showed synaptic connectivity by labeling pre- and postsynaptic proteins. Fig 6: Two-color imaging identified GABAergic interneurons as postsynaptic targets of mossy fibers.
application_goal: The protocol enabled rapid, high-resolution imaging of large neuronal populations, allowing detailed analysis of neural circuits and synaptic connectivity in mouse brain samples.
novelty: This study combines expansion microscopy with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy to achieve super-resolution imaging of large brain volumes. Compared to previous methods, this approach offers a significant speed advantage and improved resolution, enabling detailed connectivity mapping. The use of expansion microscopy renders samples transparent, facilitating light-sheet imaging without the need for additional clearing techniques. This work advances the field by providing a practical solution for high-speed, high-resolution volumetric imaging of neural circuits.

title: Enhanced synaptic protein visualization by multicolor super-resolution expansion microscopy
authors: Janna Eilts, Sebastian Reinhard, Nikolas Michetschläger, Christian Werner, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates post-expansion immunolabeling of synaptic proteins in hippocampal neurons, showing improved labeling density and reduced linkage error. Fig 2: Illustrates four-color imaging of synaptic proteins, revealing spatial organization and alignment of pre- and postsynaptic proteins. The method achieves 20-30 nm resolution, enabling detailed visualization of synaptic structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of synaptic protein organization in neurons, allowing for multicolor imaging with high resolution. This approach provides insights into the spatial arrangement of proteins at synapses, which is crucial for understanding synaptic function and plasticity.
novelty: This study presents a significant advancement in expansion microscopy by achieving multicolor imaging with 20-30 nm resolution, surpassing the limitations of previous super-resolution methods that were restricted to fewer colors and lower resolutions. The use of post-expansion immunolabeling and a robust expansion factor of 8x allows for high-density labeling and minimal linkage error, providing a clearer view of synaptic protein organization. Compared to prior ExM variants, this method offers improved resolution and the ability to visualize multiple proteins simultaneously, enhancing the study of synaptic structures.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals thylakoid organisation alterations due to genetic mutations and far-red light acclimation
authors: Jarne Berentsen, Peter R. Bos, Emilie Wientjes
summary: Fig 1: Compared granum diameters in enveloped chloroplasts and isolated thylakoids, showing no significant difference. Fig 2: Visualized thylakoid membranes of WT, FR-acclimated WT, and curt1a plants, highlighting structural differences. Fig 3: Z-stacks of thylakoids revealed 3D architecture and granum connections. Fig 4: 3D reconstructions showed less organized thylakoid membranes in curt1a mutants. Fig 5: Measured granum diameters and interspaces, showing increased diameters in FR-acclimated and curt1a thylakoids. Fig 6: Analyzed granum height, stroma lamellae distance, and wrapping angles, indicating structural changes in different conditions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution 3D imaging of thylakoid membranes, allowing for detailed analysis of structural changes due to environmental conditions and genetic mutations. This approach provides insights into the dynamic architecture of thylakoids and their role in photosynthesis.
novelty: This study presents an optimized ExM protocol for Arabidopsis thaliana thylakoids, expanding its application beyond spinach. The work highlights the ability of ExM to visualize thylakoid architecture changes due to far-red light acclimation and CURT1A mutations, offering a resolution advantage over conventional microscopy. The study demonstrates ExM's potential to provide high-throughput, high-resolution 3D images, which are crucial for understanding thylakoid dynamics and photosynthetic efficiency. Compared to previous methods, this approach offers a more accessible and less time-consuming alternative for studying complex membrane structures.

title: Expansion Microscopy of trichomonads
authors: Paula Terra Bandeira, Sharmila Fiama das Neves Ortiz, Marlene Benchimol, Wanderley de Souza
summary: Fig 1: Phase contrast microscopy shows expanded T. foetus cells, revealing internal structures like hydrogenosomes and vacuoles. Fig 2: Fluorescence microscopy of T. vaginalis and T. foetus highlights axostyle microtubules and costa using immunostaining. Fig 3: Immunofluorescence microscopy shows costa fragmentation in expanded cells, indicating protein distribution throughout the structure.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the cytoskeletal structures in T. vaginalis and T. foetus, improving the localization of proteins like tubulin and costain 1. This enhanced resolution aids in understanding the structural organization of these protozoa, which are agents of trichomoniasis.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to trichomonads, providing higher resolution images of their cytoskeleton compared to conventional methods. The use of ExM allowed for the first-time visualization of individualized microtubules in the axostyle and homogeneous labeling of the costa. This work builds on previous ExM techniques by adapting protocols for protozoa, offering insights into their unique structures.

title: Imaging Giardia intestinalis cellular organisation using expansion microscopy reveals atypical centrin localisation
authors: J. Soukup, M. Zelen´a, F. Weisz, M. Kostelansk´a, E. Nohýnkov´a, P. Tůmov´a
summary: Fig 1: The ExM workflow for Giardia cells was optimized to ensure uniform orientation and cell density, improving imaging efficiency. Fig 2: ExM resolved Giardia's microtubular cytoskeleton and organelles, enhancing visualization of cellular structures. Fig 3: ExM provided detailed centrin localization, revealing non-luminal positioning at basal bodies. Fig 4: 3D reconstructions confirmed centrin's atypical arrangement, suggesting a unique structural role.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of Giardia intestinalis cellular structures without the need for superresolution microscopy, allowing detailed visualization of centrin localization and other subcellular components.
novelty: This study presents a modified ExM protocol for Giardia intestinalis that does not require superresolution equipment, unlike previous methods combining ExM with SIM or confocal microscopy. The use of post-expansion labeling improved epitope accessibility and resolution, revealing novel centrin localization patterns not previously observed. The protocol's simplicity and reliance on conventional confocal microscopy make it accessible for routine use, offering a significant advancement in imaging protist cellular organization.

title: Aptamer-based expansion microscopy platform enables signal-amplified imaging of dendritic spines
authors: Yuting Zhuo, Bo Fu, Ruizi Peng, Changbei Ma, Sitao Xie, Liping Qiu
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the aptamer-based ExM strategy for imaging dendritic spines (DS) with enhanced resolution. Fig 2 demonstrates the effective enlargement of nuclei and neurites using ExM, highlighting the method's capability to enhance structural details. Fig 3 shows the signal amplification achieved through hybridization chain reaction (HCR), significantly improving fluorescence intensity. Fig 4 combines HCR with ExM to visualize DS, revealing more detailed structures and demonstrating the platform's potential for high-resolution imaging. The study concludes with the application of this method to evaluate early ischemic stroke by observing morphological changes in DS.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of dendritic spines, providing enhanced structural details and signal amplification. This advancement allows for the study of nanoscale structures in biological systems, particularly in the context of ischemia-induced early stroke, by revealing morphological changes in dendritic spines.
novelty: This work introduces an aptamer-based expansion microscopy (ExM) platform combined with hybridization chain reaction (HCR) for signal amplification. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach offers enhanced sensitivity and resolution without the need for expensive equipment. The use of aptamers as recognition ligands provides advantages over antibodies, such as smaller size and easier modification. The integration of HCR addresses the issue of fluorescence dilution during expansion, setting this method apart from traditional ExM techniques.

title: Mechanical expansion microscopy
authors: Yuhang Fan, Youngbin Lim, Livia S. Wyss, Seongjin Park, Cancan Xue, Huikang Fu, Jingyi Fei, Yi Hong, Bo Wang
summary: The paper introduces mechanical expansion microscopy techniques, focusing on two main approaches: mechanically resolved and mechanically locked expansion microscopy. The authors describe the rationale, materials, and protocols for applying these techniques to bacterial cells. The discussion highlights the potential of these methods for achieving super-resolution imaging. The paper concludes with a discussion on the implications and future directions of these techniques.
application_goal: The protocol enables super-resolution imaging of bacterial cells by employing mechanical expansion techniques.
novelty: This work introduces mechanical expansion microscopy, which differs from prior ExM variants by focusing on mechanical methods to achieve expansion, potentially offering new avenues for super-resolution imaging.

title: Expansion microscopy of the mitotic spindle
authors: Ivana Ponjavic, Kruno Vukusic, Iva M. Tolic
summary: Fig 1: Protocol for expansion microscopy of tubulin in the spindle is detailed, highlighting its importance for spindle structure visualization. Fig 2: Protocol for expansion microscopy of PRC1-GFP is presented, emphasizing its role in microtubule bundle analysis. Fig 3: Comparison of visualization approaches for the bridging fiber, demonstrating improved resolution post-expansion. Fig 4: Estimation of microtubule numbers in the bridging fiber, showcasing the method's quantitative capabilities. Fig 5: Analysis of PRC1-GFP on microtubule bundles in expanded spindles, illustrating enhanced structural insights.
application_goal: The protocol enables detailed visualization and analysis of the mitotic spindle, allowing for improved resolution and quantitative assessment of microtubule structures.
novelty: This study advances expansion microscopy by applying it to the mitotic spindle, a complex cellular structure. Compared to previous ExM variants, this work focuses on spindle-specific proteins like tubulin and PRC1-GFP, providing new insights into spindle architecture. The method enhances resolution and allows for quantitative analysis of microtubule bundles, which is a significant improvement over traditional microscopy techniques.

title: Mapping the neuronal cytoskeleton using expansion microscopy
authors: Daphne Jurriens, Vincent van Batenburg, Eugene A. Katrukha, Lukas C. Kapitein
summary: Fig 1: Describes the sample preparation process for cell culture and immunofluorescence. Fig 2: Details the digestion and expansion steps, crucial for visualizing the neuronal cytoskeleton. Fig 3: Shows the imaging acquisition and analysis, highlighting the improved resolution. Fig 4: Demonstrates the application of the protocol to image microtubule subsets in neurons, emphasizing its utility in neurobiology.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the neuronal cytoskeleton, allowing for the study of microtubule subsets in neurons with enhanced clarity.
novelty: This study presents an optimized protocol for expansion microscopy, focusing on the neuronal cytoskeleton. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach offers improved visualization of microtubule subsets, which is critical for understanding neuronal structure and function. The work highlights the potential of expansion microscopy in neurobiological research, providing a new tool for detailed cellular analysis.

title: Enhanced expansion microscopy to measure nanoscale structural and biochemical remodeling in single cells
authors: Thomas M.D. Sheard, Izzy Jayasinghe
summary: Fig 1: Introduction to enhanced expansion microscopy and its application to cardiac nanodomains. Fig 2: Detailed methods for enhanced expansion microscopy, including preparation and imaging. Fig 3: Resolution principles and practical applications in biological structures. Fig 4: Comparison of structure verification with DNA-PAINT. Fig 5: 3D imaging techniques for biological samples. Fig 6: Visualization of pathological and physiological alterations. Fig 7: Validation of isotropy in expanded samples.
application_goal: The protocol enables detailed visualization of nanoscale structural and biochemical changes in single cells, providing insights into cellular remodeling processes.
novelty: This work enhances traditional expansion microscopy by focusing on single-cell analysis, allowing for the measurement of nanoscale changes. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach emphasizes isotropy and resolution verification, particularly in cardiac nanodomains. The study does not introduce new chemistry but refines existing techniques for improved structural analysis.
variant_semantic: nanoscale subcellular structures (e.g., membrane nanodomains, sarcomeric components, organelles)

title: Expansion STED microscopy (ExSTED)
authors: Mengfei Gao, Ria Thielhorn, Jakob Rentsch, Alf Honigmann, Helge Ewers
application_goal: The protocol enables the combination of expansion microscopy with STED microscopy to achieve higher resolution imaging of biological samples, allowing for more detailed visualization of cellular structures.
novelty: This work introduces a novel integration of expansion microscopy with STED microscopy, termed ExSTED, which enhances the resolution capabilities beyond what is achievable with either technique alone. This approach allows for the visualization of finer cellular details, providing a significant advancement over previous ExM variants.
figure_walkthrough: The paper begins with an introduction to the concept of Expansion STED microscopy (ExSTED), highlighting its potential to enhance resolution in biological imaging. The subsequent sections detail the optimization of ExM sample preparation specifically for STED microscopy, including the choice of fixation strategy and crosslinking reagents. The authors provide a step-by-step guide on the expansion procedure and sample mounting, followed by STED image acquisition and data analysis. Example images are presented to demonstrate the improved resolution achieved with ExSTED.

title: Application of expansion microscopy on developing Arabidopsis seeds
authors: Ping Kao, Michael D. Nodine
summary: Fig 1: Sample collection and fixation methods are detailed, crucial for preserving seed structure. Fig 2: Cell wall digestion and membrane permeabilization techniques are optimized to enhance imaging clarity. Fig 3: Seed isolation and monomer incubation processes are described, ensuring effective expansion. Fig 4: Gelation and expansion steps are outlined, critical for achieving desired expansion ratios. Fig 5: Fluorescent immunostaining is applied to visualize proteins, providing insights into cellular activities.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of cellular activities and subcellular structures in developing Arabidopsis seeds, enhancing our understanding of seed development processes.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to plant seeds, a relatively unexplored sample type in ExM studies. By optimizing cell wall digestion and membrane permeabilization, the authors achieve improved imaging clarity. The work builds on previous ExM techniques by adapting them for plant tissues, offering new insights into plant development. Unlike prior ExM variants focused on animal tissues, this study expands the applicability of ExM to plant biology.

title: A protocol to expand plant nuclei
authors: Ivona Kubalova´a, Marketa Schmidt Cernohorska´, Martina Huranova´, Klaus Weisshart, Andreas Houben, Veit Schubert
summary: The paper presents a protocol for expanding plant nuclei, detailing the materials and methods used in the process. The introduction provides background information on the importance of studying plant nuclei and the potential benefits of expansion microscopy in this context. The results section discusses the outcomes of applying the protocol, highlighting any improvements in visualization or analysis of plant nuclei. The conclusion summarizes the findings and suggests potential applications or future directions for research.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the expansion of plant nuclei, allowing for improved visualization and analysis of their structure and components.
novelty: This work introduces a protocol specifically tailored for expanding plant nuclei, which is a novel application of expansion microscopy compared to prior variants that primarily focused on animal cells or tissues.

title: Expansion microscopy on Drosophila spermatocyte centrioles
authors: Alan Wainman
summary: Fig 1: Preparation of Drosophila centriole samples is detailed, highlighting the importance of sample integrity. Fig 2: Pro-ExM protocol for testes preparations is described, emphasizing its role in preserving structural details. Fig 3: Modified U-ExM method is introduced, showcasing its utility in preventing protein crosslinking. Fig 4: Immunofluorescence imaging techniques are outlined, demonstrating enhanced visualization of centrioles. Fig 5: Super-resolution imaging of expanded samples is presented, underscoring improvements in image quality.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of Drosophila spermatocyte centrioles, allowing for precise measurement of centriole size and isotropic expansion. This approach provides a robust framework for studying centriole architecture and function in a model organism.
novelty: This study compares pro-ExM and modified U-ExM techniques, highlighting the latter's ability to prevent protein crosslinking, which is a significant advancement over previous ExM variants. The combination with structured illumination microscopy further enhances resolution, offering a novel approach to studying centrioles in Drosophila. This work sets a new standard for expansion microscopy by integrating advanced imaging techniques with refined sample preparation methods.

title: Improving the resolution of fluorescence nanoscopy using post-expansion labeling microscopy
authors: Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard
summary: The paper discusses the use of post-expansion labeling microscopy to improve the resolution of fluorescence nanoscopy. It outlines the differences between pre- and post-expansion labeling techniques, emphasizing the advantages of the latter in reducing linkage errors and improving labeling efficiency. The authors explore methods to enhance structural resolution, aiming to advance structural cell biology using expansion microscopy (ExM). The chapter concludes with a discussion on the potential of these techniques to provide more detailed insights into cellular structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled improved resolution in fluorescence nanoscopy by utilizing post-expansion labeling techniques. This approach reduces linkage errors and enhances labeling efficiency, allowing for more precise visualization of cellular structures. The advancements in structural resolution aim to facilitate detailed studies in structural cell biology.
novelty: The work introduces post-expansion labeling as a novel approach compared to prior ExM variants, focusing on reducing linkage errors and improving labeling efficiency. This method enhances the resolution of fluorescence nanoscopy, providing a more detailed view of cellular structures and advancing the field of structural cell biology.

title: EASI-FISH for thick tissue defines lateral hypothalamus spatio-molecular organization
authors: Yuhan Wang, Mark Eddison, Greg Fleishman, Martin Weigert, Shengjin Xu, Tim Wang, Konrad Rokicki, Cristian Goina, Fredrick E. Henry, Andrew L. Lemire, Uwe Schmidt, Hui Yang, Karel Svoboda, Eugene W. Myers, Stephan Saalfeld, Wyatt Korff, Scott M. Sternson, Paul W. Tillberg
summary: Fig 1: EASI-FISH method was developed for thick tissue sections to map gene expression. Fig 2: A computational pipeline was created for processing large EASI-FISH datasets. Fig 3: EASI-FISH was applied to the mouse lateral hypothalamic area, revealing spatial organization of cell types. Fig 4: Machine learning was used to identify LHA subregions based on gene expression. Fig 5: Molecularly defined cell types and axonal projections were mapped in LHA subregions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled robust gene expression profiling in thick brain slices, facilitating the reconstruction of spatio-molecular domains that generalize across brains. It also allowed for the iterative reanalysis of scRNA-seq datasets to determine marker-genes that further dissociate spatial and morphological heterogeneity.
novelty: EASI-FISH extends the capabilities of traditional FISH by enabling multiplexed RNA-FISH in thick tissue sections, overcoming the limitations of thin section methods. The use of Melphalan as an anchoring agent improves RNA retention and signal-to-noise ratio. The study provides a detailed molecular map of the lateral hypothalamic area, revealing new subregions and cell type distributions not previously identified.

title: Protein-retention expansion microscopy for visualizing subcellular organelles in fixed brain tissue
authors: Logan A. Campbell, Katy E. Pannoni, Niesha A. Savory, Dinesh Lal, Shannon Farris
summary: Fig 1: Compared ExM immunostaining and digestion conditions for organelles in fixed brain tissue, highlighting the importance of IHC order. Fig 2: Demonstrated that IHC-pre with proteinase K digestion best preserves fluorescence for mitochondria and reporter labeling. Fig 3: Showed that GOLGA5-labeled Golgi are best visualized with IHC-pre and proteinase K digestion. Fig 4: Analyzed digestion time effects, finding 8-hour digestion optimal for expansion and fluorescence retention. Fig 5: Confirmed minimal distortion and enhanced resolution of Golgi post-ExM.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular organelles, such as mitochondria and Golgi apparatus, in fixed mouse brain tissue with improved resolution and fluorescence retention, facilitating accurate quantification and structural analysis.
novelty: This study optimized a proExM protocol for fixed brain tissue, achieving ~70 nm resolution without super-resolution microscopy. The use of proteinase K digestion for 8 hours was crucial for balancing expansion and fluorescence retention, offering a practical approach for visualizing organelles in densely packed tissues. Compared to previous ExM variants, this protocol provides a robust method for organelle visualization in brain tissue, addressing challenges in fluorescence signal retention and tissue distortion.

title: Proteus mirabilis biofilm expansion microscopy yields over 4-fold magnification for super-resolution of biofilm structure and subcellular DNA organization
authors: Dante Castagnini, Karina Palma, Jorge Jara-Wilde, Nicolás Navarro, María José González, Jorge Toledo, Nicole Canales-Huerta, Paola Scavone, Steffen Härtel
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the need for capsule, cell-wall, and protein degradation for expansion of planktonic P. mirabilis. Fig 2 shows the three-step protocol for biofilm expansion, highlighting the need for enzymatic digestion. Fig 3 confirms over 4-fold expansion without gross distortions in morphology and spatial organization. Fig 4 illustrates improved lateral and axial resolution of biofilms, revealing structural features. Fig 5 reveals novel spatial organization patterns of DNA in biofilms, showing different fluorescent staining patterns.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization and analysis of P. mirabilis biofilm architecture and intracellular features, such as DNA organization, by achieving over 4-fold isotropic expansion. This allows for super-resolution studies using conventional fluorescence microscopy.
novelty: This study presents PmbExM, a novel ExM protocol variant for P. mirabilis biofilms, achieving the maximum theoretical expansion factor of 4.3x. Unlike previous ExM variants, PmbExM does not require pre-gelation digestion, preserving bacterial structures before gelation. The protocol effectively homogenizes biofilm components, allowing for detailed study of biofilm architecture and intracellular features. This work expands the applicability of ExM to bacterial biofilms, providing a cost-effective and accessible super-resolution method.

title: Isotropic multi-scale neuronal reconstruction from high-ratio expansion microscopy with contrastive unsupervised deep generative models
authors: Gary Han Chang, Meng-Yun Wu, Ling-Hui Yen, Da-Yu Huang, Ya-Hui Lin, Yi-Ru Luo, Ya-Ding Liu, Bin Xu, Kam W. Leong, Wen-Sung Lai, Ann-Shyn Chiang, Kuo-Chuan Wang, Chin-Hsien Lin, Shih-Luen Wang, Li-An Chu
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the IsoGAN model for isotropic neuronal reconstruction, addressing anisotropic resolution issues. Fig 2: Demonstrates IsoGAN's ability to enhance axial resolution and reduce imaging artifacts in DPM neurons. Fig 3: Shows IsoGAN's generalization across various biological samples, including VMAT proteins and human brain tissues. Fig 4: Compares IsoGAN with other models, highlighting its superior image enhancement capabilities. Fig 5: Illustrates IsoGAN's effectiveness in reconstructing neuronal structures from uneven background signals.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the reconstruction of isotropic images of neuronal structures from high-ratio expansion microscopy data, significantly reducing the need for manual annotation and improving the accuracy of neuronal morphology analysis.
novelty: This study introduces the IsoGAN model, which leverages contrastive unsupervised deep generative models to overcome the limitations of anisotropic resolution in expansion microscopy. Unlike previous methods that require extensive manual annotation, IsoGAN uses multi-scale deconvolution components to enhance image quality and resolution. The model's ability to generalize across different biological samples and its unsupervised learning approach represent significant advancements over traditional supervised methods.

title: Human skeletal muscle cell atlas: Unraveling cellular secrets utilizing ‘muscle-on-a-chip’, differential expansion microscopy, mass spectrometry, nanothermometry and machine learning
authors: Bhanu P. Jena, Domenico L. Gatti, Suzan Arslanturk, Sebastian Pernal, Douglas J. Taatjes

model_system: primary human skeletal muscle cell cultures

summary: Fig 1: DExM was used to image human skeletal muscle cells, highlighting the spatial organization of nuclei and myosin filaments, crucial for understanding muscle function. Fig 2: Transmission electron microscopy provided detailed images of the spatial localization of nuclei and mitochondria, essential for studying muscle cell energy dynamics. Fig 3: Deep learning models were applied to predict muscle cell morphology and function from DExM images, offering insights into muscle adaptation. Fig 4: A schematic integration of technologies was presented to create a comprehensive human skeletal muscle cell atlas, aiding in disease diagnosis and therapy development.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the creation of a detailed atlas of human skeletal muscle cells, providing insights into their structure, chemistry, and function. This atlas serves as a reference for understanding muscle cell dynamics in health and disease, facilitating the development of precision therapeutics and aiding in the diagnosis of muscle-related pathologies.
novelty: This study introduces Differential Expansion Microscopy (DExM), which improves upon traditional Expansion Microscopy by retaining organelle integrity and spatial relationships. Unlike previous methods, DExM allows for nanometer-scale imaging of muscle cells without compromising the ratio of subcellular structures. The integration of machine learning further distinguishes this work, enabling predictive modeling of muscle cell states and enhancing the understanding of muscle adaptation and disease.

title: Multiplexed expansion microscopy of the brain through fluorophore screening
authors: Kyeongbae Min, In Cho, Myunghwan Choi, Jae-Byum Chang
summary: Fig 1: Compared brightness of fluorophores in BS-C-1 cells to identify optimal candidates for ExM. Fig 2: Evaluated microtubule staining to confirm fluorophore performance. Fig 5: Compared CF and Alexa fluorophores, showing CF's superior brightness. Fig 6: Achieved 5-color imaging by photobleaching and re-staining with DAPI.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the identification of a set of fluorophores that retain high brightness after expansion, allowing for high-quality 4-color and 5-color imaging of brain tissue. This facilitates detailed visualization of cellular structures and protein localization in expanded samples.
novelty: This study advances ExM by optimizing fluorophore selection, achieving superior brightness and signal retention compared to traditional Alexa dyes. The work introduces a method for 5-color imaging using photobleaching and re-staining, expanding the capabilities of ExM without additional lasers. This approach simplifies high-resolution imaging by eliminating the need for complex signal amplification, as required in iterative ExM, while maintaining structural integrity and resolution.

title: Ultrastructural expansion microscopy (U-ExM) visualization of malaria parasite dense granules using RESA as a representative marker protein
authors: Junpei Fukumoto, Takafumi Tsuboi, Eizo Takashima
summary: Fig 1: U-ExM was used to identify rhoptry and microneme organelles in malaria parasites, highlighting the method's ability to visualize subcellular structures. Fig 2: Anti-RESA antibody was employed to map dense granules throughout the asexual life cycle of parasites, demonstrating U-ExM's utility in identifying protein localization. The study confirms RESA localization in merozoites and its translocation to the erythrocyte membrane, aligning with previous IEM findings.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of dense granules in Plasmodium falciparum merozoites using U-ExM, facilitating the identification of novel DG proteins without the need for time-consuming immunoelectron microscopy. This advancement enhances the understanding of erythrocyte parasitism by P. falciparum.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of U-ExM to visualize dense granules in malaria parasites, offering a significant improvement over traditional IEM by eliminating the need for complex sample preparation and antibody generation. The use of U-ExM allows for the expansion of fixed cells to approximately four times their original size, providing higher localization resolutions than super-resolution microscopy. This approach is particularly novel in its application to dense granules, which have not been previously characterized using U-ExM, and it holds potential for identifying new protein localizations in both laboratory strains and field isolates.

title: Expansion microscopy allows quantitative characterization of structural organization of platelet aggregates
authors: Emma L. Faulkner, Jeremy A. Pike, Evelyn Garlick, Robert K. Neely, Iain B. Styles, Stephen P. Watson, Natalie S. Poulter, Steven G. Thomas
summary: Fig 1: ExM preparation of platelets enables nanoscale resolution and increases imaging depth and volume. Fig 2: ExM reveals heterogeneous distribution of membrane and cytoskeletal components in platelet aggregates. Fig 3: Custom analysis workﬂows allow quantitative descriptions of aggregates and platelets. Fig 4: Classiﬁcation of actin localization in segmented platelets shows membrane and cytoplasmic distribution. Fig 5: Actin inhibitors disrupt structural organization in preformed platelet aggregates. Fig 6: Quantitative analysis reveals subtle changes in platelet morphology and actin distribution after inhibitor treatment.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and quantitative analysis of the structural organization of platelet aggregates at nanoscale resolution, providing insights into the heterogeneous distribution of membrane and cytoskeletal components. This approach allows for the detailed study of platelet morphology and actin organization, which is crucial for understanding thrombus stability and formation.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy (ExM) to platelet aggregates, overcoming limitations of traditional microscopy techniques in resolving subcellular features within dense and optically opaque samples. The use of ExM provides nanoscale resolution and optical clearing, facilitating volumetric imaging of platelet aggregates. The study introduces a custom analysis workflow for quantitative descriptions of platelet morphology and actin organization, offering a comprehensive approach to studying thrombus architecture. Compared to prior ExM variants, this work highlights the ability to capture 3D structural organization of thousands of individual platelets within aggregates, providing a more detailed understanding of thrombus composition and stability.

title: Expansion mini-microscopy: An enabling alternative in point-of-care diagnostics
authors: Yu Shrike Zhang, Grissel Trujillo-de Santiago, Mario Moisés Alvarez, Steven J. Schiff, Edward S. Boyden, Ali Khademhosseini
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the expansion of biological samples using sodium polyacrylate, achieving isotropic expansion and improved resolution. Figure 2 illustrates the application of proExM for protein retention and ExFISH for RNA imaging, showing enhanced resolution in mouse hippocampus. Figure 3 showcases various portable microscopes, highlighting their compact design and application in imaging biological samples. Figure 4 presents ExMM, combining ExM with mini-microscopy, achieving high-resolution imaging of HEK293 cells and E. coli, comparable to conventional microscopes.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of biological specimens using low-cost mini-microscopes, making it feasible for point-of-care diagnostics in resource-limited settings. By physically expanding samples, ExMM achieves resolutions comparable to high-end microscopes without the need for expensive equipment.
novelty: This work introduces expansion mini-microscopy (ExMM), combining expansion microscopy with mini-microscopes to achieve high-resolution imaging at a fraction of the cost of conventional methods. Unlike previous ExM variants, ExMM leverages low-cost, portable devices, making it accessible for point-of-care diagnostics. The use of sodium polyacrylate for expansion and the integration with mini-microscopy represents a significant advancement in making super-resolution imaging more affordable and widespread.

title: Expansion microscopy-based imaging of nuclear structures in cultured cells
authors: Antoine Gaudreau-Lapierre, Kirk Mulatz, Jean-Claude Be´ ı¨que, Laura Trinkle-Mulcahy
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the tenfold expansion of fixed and stained cultured cells with concurrent DNA staining, highlighting the use of a custom 3D-printed gel cutter to minimize drift. Fig 2 shows Airyscan and Imaris-based imaging and volume rendering of nuclear structures, emphasizing the nanoscale resolution achieved. Fig 3 details the approach to calculate the expansion factor using Fiji open-source software, underscoring the precision of the method.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nuclear structures at nanoscale resolution in cultured human cells, allowing for detailed analysis of spatial relationships between fluorophore-labeled proteins.
novelty: This study utilizes the X10 method for a tenfold expansion, which is a significant improvement over the original 4.5x expansion factor. The integration of a custom 3D-printed gel cutter and chambered slides minimizes gel drift, enhancing imaging stability. The combination with Airyscan confocal imaging provides a higher resolution than traditional methods, offering a more detailed view of nuclear structures.

title: Visualization of the membrane surface and cytoskeleton of oligodendrocyte progenitor cell growth cones using a combination of scanning ion conductance and four times expansion microscopy
authors: Annika Haak, Heiko M. Lesslich, Irmgard D. Dietzel
summary: Figure 1: The workflow for imaging OPC growth cones using SICM and ExM is outlined, highlighting the correlation of membrane topography and cytoskeletal structures. Figure 2: SICM captures detailed topographies of OPC growth cones, revealing membrane protrusions and cytoskeletal organization. Figure 3: ExM images show expanded OPCs, allowing visualization of microtubules with high resolution. Figure 4: Correlation of SICM and ExM images demonstrates the alignment of microtubules with membrane topographies. Figure 5: Dual staining of actin and tubulin in ExM images shows distinct localization patterns in OPC growth cones.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of the relative positions of actin and tubulin fibers with respect to membrane protrusions in OPC growth cones, providing insights into the cytoskeletal organization and membrane topography at resolutions below 200 nm.
novelty: This study presents a novel combination of scanning ion conductance microscopy (SICM) and expansion microscopy (ExM) to achieve high-resolution imaging of oligodendrocyte progenitor cell (OPC) growth cones. Unlike previous methods that required complex setups, this approach allows for the visualization of membrane topographies and cytoskeletal structures using standard widefield microscopy. The integration of SICM with ExM provides a unique advantage by correlating surface and intracellular structures, offering a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution techniques like STED or SOFI. The use of a 4x expansion factor further enhances the resolution, enabling detailed analysis of nanostructures.

title: Expansion microscopy with carboxylic trifunctional linkers
authors: Xuecheng Chen, Yaqian Li, Jiabin Wang, Jielin Sun, Daniel M. Czajkowsky, Zhifeng Shao
summary: Figure 1 illustrates the synthesis of trifunctional linkers and their attachment to antibodies. Figure 2A demonstrates the labeling of microtubule filaments in COS-7 cells, showing negligible distortion after expansion. Figure 2E shows simultaneous imaging of DNA, nuclear pore complexes, and nuclear lamina in U2OS cells, revealing correlative features at a resolution of ~24 nm. The study confirms the method's versatility and high efficiency with different hapten-TLs.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the effective attachment of labels onto the hydrogel for routine expansion microscopy, making the method accessible to most biological labs. It allows for high-resolution imaging of biological structures at tens of nanometers, using antibodies, nanobodies, or click chemistry.
novelty: This work introduces a simplified synthesis of trifunctional linkers for expansion microscopy, making the method more accessible compared to previous approaches that required complex organic chemistry techniques. The use of carboxylic trifunctional linkers provides strong anchoring and high fluorescence retention, improving upon traditional ExM methods. The study demonstrates the method's effectiveness in achieving high-resolution imaging comparable to single molecule localization microscopy.

title: Expansion microscopy with trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification (TT-ExM) for protein and lipid staining
authors: Ueh-Ting Tim Wang, Xuejiao Tian, Yae-Huei Liou, Sue-Ping Lee, Chieh-Han Lu, Peilin Chen, Bi-Chang Che
summary: Fig 1: Introduces TT-ExM, highlighting trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification to enhance fluorescence. Fig 2: Demonstrates improved protein retention and fluorescence in COS-7 cells using TT-ExM. Fig 3: Compares trypsin and proteinase K, showing better signal retention with trypsin. Fig 4: Applies TT-ExM for lipid staining, revealing detailed cellular structures. Fig 5: Visualizes mitochondria and nuclei in cultured neurons, showcasing TT-ExM's applicability to neuronal imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled enhanced visualization of protein and lipid structures in cells, overcoming limitations of traditional expansion microscopy by improving fluorescence signal retention and intensity.
novelty: TT-ExM introduces a novel combination of trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification, improving upon previous ExM methods by enhancing fluorescence retention and signal intensity. This approach allows for detailed imaging of protein and lipid structures without the need for advanced microscopy equipment, offering a significant improvement over traditional ExM and super-resolution techniques.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals unique ultrastructural features of pathogenic budding yeast species
authors: Md. Hashim Reza, Srijana Dutta, Rohit Goyal, Hiral Shah, Gautam Dey, Kaustuv Sanyal
summary: Fig 1: Optimized U-ExM protocol for C. albicans, showing 4.24x expansion and sub-cellular organization. Fig 2: Mitochondrial network visualized, confirming mitochondria segregation before nuclear segregation. Fig 3: Nucleolar dynamics observed, with nucleolus segregating alongside chromatin. Fig 4: SPB organization studied, revealing asymmetry and Tub4 distribution. Fig 5: U-ExM applied to other fungal pathogens, showing sub-cellular structures and SPB arrangements.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of sub-cellular structures in C. albicans and other fungal pathogens, revealing unique SPB arrangements and organellar dynamics, which are critical for understanding cell division and pathogenicity.
novelty: This study extends U-ExM to several human fungal pathogens, revealing unique SPB arrangements not seen in S. cerevisiae. The work highlights the power of U-ExM in studying non-model organisms, overcoming limitations of conventional microscopy. The study also demonstrates the compatibility of U-ExM with dual dye and immunostaining, providing insights into organellar dynamics and protein distribution.

title: One step 4x and 12x 3D-ExM: robust super-resolution microscopy in cell biology
authors: Roshan X Norman, Yu-Chia Chen, Emma E Recchia, Jonathan Loi, Quincy Rosemarie, Sydney L Lesko, Smit Patel, Nathan Sherer, Motoki Takaku, Mark E Burkard, Aussie Suzuki
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the workflow of 4x and 12x 3D-ExM, highlighting the single-step expansion process. Fig 2 demonstrates isotropic expansion of nuclei in HeLa and PtK2 cells, validating the method's robustness. Fig 3 confirms isotropic expansion through correlative pre- and post-expansion imaging. Fig 4 shows successful application of 12x 3D-ExM to 3D organoid models, expanding nuclei by 12-fold. Fig 5 validates sub-30 nm resolution by measuring microtubule diameters using confocal and STED microscopy. Fig 6 reveals detailed viral and cellular structures, such as EBV virions and HIV-1 RNA, using 12x 3D-ExM.
application_goal: The protocol enables robust and reproducible 3D isotropic expansion of biological samples, allowing for detailed visualization of nanoscale structures such as chromosomes, kinetochores, and viral particles. This method provides a cost-effective and user-friendly approach to super-resolution microscopy, making it accessible for a wide range of cell biology research.
novelty: This study introduces a single-step 4x and 12x 3D-ExM method that achieves sub-30 nm resolution without the need for specialized equipment or iterative processes. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method simplifies the expansion process while maintaining isotropy and structural integrity. The use of DMAA-based polymerization and glutaraldehyde crosslinking represents a novel approach, enabling greater expansion factors and improved resolution over traditional ExM techniques.

title: IntAct-U-ExM: Ultrastructure Expansion microscopy of actin networks via an internally-tagged actin
authors: Anubhav Dhar, Nishaant Kumar Palani Balaji, Sanjana Mullick, Sucheta Dey, Angana Ghosh, Deepak Nair, Sudarshan Gadadhar, Saravanan Palani
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of IntAct-U-ExM to visualize actin structures in yeast, highlighting improved detection of actin cables post-expansion. Fig 2 extends this to mammalian cells, showing isoform-specific visualization of actin networks in U2OS cells. The study emphasizes the method's ability to reveal nuclear actin filaments, underscoring its potential for uncovering new actin structures. The results validate IntAct-U-ExM as a robust tool for super-resolution imaging of actin across species.
application_goal: The protocol enabled isoform-specific visualization of actin networks in both yeast and mammalian cells, allowing for detailed study of actin structures at nanoscale resolution. This approach facilitates the exploration of actin's role in various cellular processes and compartments, providing insights into the organization and function of actin networks.
novelty: This work introduces IntAct-U-ExM, a novel approach for super-resolution imaging of actin networks, offering isoform-specific visualization that was previously challenging with existing ExM protocols. Compared to prior methods, IntAct-U-ExM provides enhanced resolution and compatibility with U-ExM, enabling the study of actin structures in diverse model systems. The use of an internally tagged actin variant represents a significant advancement in the field, allowing for detailed exploration of actin's nanoscale architecture.

title: Mapping EGFR1 sorting domains in endosomes with a calibrated 3D expansion microscopy toolkit
authors: Tayla Shakespeare, Rajpinder S. Seehra, Neftali Flores Rodriguez, Nkolika Atuanya, Thomas M.D. Sheard, Ralf Köhler, Daniel Bose, Philip Woodman, Barbara Ciani, Izzy Jayasinghe
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the 3D ExM method for visualizing endosomal proteins in RPE-1 cells, highlighting the improved resolution of endosomal structures. Fig 2: Introduces a protein nanocage as a nanoscale reporter for intrinsic gel expansion, providing a calibration method for ExM. Fig 3: Details the pulse-chase experiments to visualize EGF and EGFR1 sorting, showing nanoscale domains of EGFR1 clustering. Fig 4: Explores the 3D organization of EGFR1 sorting proteins, revealing the spatial relationships between EGF, EGFR1, Rab5a, and endofin.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and quantification of nanoscale domains of endosomal proteins, providing insights into the sorting and internalization processes of EGFR1 in endosomes. This approach allows for the mapping of protein distributions within maturing endosomes, offering a framework for studying small sub-cellular organelles at molecular-scale resolution.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of 10x ExM combined with Airyscan microscopy to achieve unprecedented 3D resolution of endosomal structures, surpassing previous super-resolution techniques. The introduction of a genetically encoded protein nanocage as a nanoscale reporter for gel expansion is a significant advancement, providing a non-destructive method for calibrating ExM images. This work enhances the spatial fidelity of ExM, offering a robust tool for quantitative molecular imaging of intracellular compartments.

title: Dual-color expansion microscopy of membrane proteins using bioorthogonal labeling
authors: Steven Edwards, Birthe Meineke, Sebastian Bauer, Hans Blom, Simon Elsässer, Hjalmar Brismar
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the incorporation of ncAAs into NKA subunits and their selective labeling using click chemistry, highlighting successful membrane localization. Figure 2 shows STED microscopy of NKA β1, revealing its nanoscale distribution in the plasma membrane. Figure 3 illustrates the ExM process, achieving super-resolution imaging of NKA β1 in expanded cells, with a detailed analysis of cluster sizes. Figure 4 presents dual-color labeling of NKA α1 and β1 subunits in expanded cells, showcasing the heterogenous distribution of these proteins.
application_goal: The protocol enabled dual-color super-resolution imaging of membrane proteins, specifically the Na,K-ATPase α1 and β1 subunits, in expanded HEK 293T cells. This approach provided nanoscale insights into the distribution of these proteins using conventional confocal microscopy, overcoming the limitations of traditional labeling methods.
novelty: This study combines genetic code expansion (GCE) with expansion microscopy (ExM) to achieve dual-color super-resolution imaging, minimizing linkage error associated with traditional antibody labeling. The use of bioorthogonal click chemistry for site-specific labeling is a significant advancement, allowing for precise localization of proteins. Compared to prior ExM variants, this method offers improved resolution and compatibility with conventional microscopes, making it accessible for broader applications in biological imaging.

title: Uniform distribution of photosystems in dark-adapted Synechocystis cells
authors: Peter R. Bos, Elio Langlois – Legrand, Emilie Wientjes
summary: Figure 1 shows the resolution of thylakoid layers in expanded Synechocystis cells, highlighting the method's ability to resolve structures previously indistinguishable. Figure 2 demonstrates the specific localization of PSI, PSII, and PBS within the thylakoid membranes using immunostaining, confirming the homogeneous distribution of these complexes. Figure 3 presents the colocalization analysis, indicating high correlation between PSI, PSII, and PBS signals, suggesting no microdomains. Figure 4 highlights exceptions in dividing cells where phycocyanin is absent, suggesting steric hindrance in confined areas.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of individual thylakoid membranes and the mapping of photosynthetic complexes in Synechocystis cells, providing insights into the spatial organization of photosynthesis without evidence of microdomains.
novelty: This study introduces cryo-ExM as a method to visualize cyanobacterial thylakoid membranes with high resolution, surpassing traditional EM and confocal microscopy. Unlike previous studies suggesting microdomains, this work shows a homogeneous distribution of photosystems in dark-adapted Synechocystis, highlighting the method's potential for studying photosynthetic efficiency without structural separation.

title: Expansion microscopy in honeybee brains for high-resolution neuroanatomical analyses in social insects
authors: Nadine Kraft, Thomas S. Muenz, Sebastian Reinhard, Christian Werner, Markus Sauer, Claudia Groh, Wolfgang Rössler
summary: Fig 1: The study introduces ExM in honeybee brains, focusing on synaptic microcircuits in mushroom bodies. Fig 2: Demonstrates the expansion process and improved resolution of synaptic structures. Fig 3: Details the distortion analysis confirming isotropic expansion. Fig 4: Shows pre- and post-expansion comparison of synapsin and BRP immunostaining. Fig 5: Quantifies BRP clusters in nurse and forager bees, revealing age-related differences. Fig 6: Provides statistical analysis of BRP cluster numbers. Fig 7: Examines GABAergic feedback neurons, showing no synapsin colocalization. Fig 8: Combines neuronal tracing with ExM, revealing detailed pre- and postsynaptic architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution visualization of synaptic microcircuits in honeybee brains, allowing for detailed analysis of age- and experience-related synaptic plasticity. It provided insights into the microarchitecture of mushroom body synapses, overcoming the diffraction limit of conventional microscopy.
novelty: This study is the first to apply ExM in a social insect, specifically the honeybee, achieving expansion factors up to 4.5x. It combines ExM with immunostaining and neuronal tracing, providing unprecedented detail in synaptic architecture. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach offers a new level of resolution and applicability in insect neuroscience, particularly in studying synaptic plasticity and connectivity.

title: Expansion Microscopy of Lipid Membranes
authors: Emmanouil D. Karagiannis, Jeong Seuk Kang, Tay Won Shin, Amauche Emenari, Shoh Asano, Leanne Lin, Emma K. Costa, IMAXT Grand Challenge Consortium, Adam H. Marblestone, Narayanan Kasthuri, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Developed a membrane probe for mExM, validated with electron microscopy for dense membrane labeling. Fig 2: Demonstrated mExM on mouse brain tissue, showing enhanced detail in expanded samples. Fig 3: Combined mExM with antibody labeling to visualize protein-lipid co-localization in organelles like ER, Golgi, mitochondria, and nuclear membrane.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of lipid membranes and their associated proteins at nanoscale resolution, allowing for detailed study of membrane structures and interactions in biological systems.
novelty: This study introduces a lipid-optimized form of expansion microscopy (mExM) that allows for the optical imaging of lipid membranes at nanoscale resolution, a capability previously limited to electron microscopy. The novel chemistry includes a membrane probe with amphiphilic properties and a polymer-anchorable handle, enabling dense membrane labeling. The post-expansion antibody labeling technique allows for simultaneous imaging of proteins and lipids, providing insights into protein-lipid interactions that were difficult to achieve with prior ExM variants.

title: HiExM: high-throughput expansion microscopy enables scalable super-resolution imaging
authors: John H Day, Catherine Marin Della Santina, Pema Maretich, Alexander L Auld, Kirsten K Schnieder, Tay Shin, Edward S Boyden, Laurie A Boyer
summary: Fig 1: HiExM device design enables gel formation and expansion in 96-well plates, crucial for high-throughput. Fig 2: HiExM achieves nanoscale resolution with minimal distortion, enhancing imaging capabilities. Fig 3: HiExM detects doxorubicin-induced nuclear changes in cardiomyocytes, demonstrating sensitivity to drug effects.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-throughput expansion microscopy in standard 96-well plates, allowing for scalable super-resolution imaging of biological samples. This method facilitates the analysis of multiple conditions and treatments simultaneously, broadening the application of ExM in biological research.
novelty: HiExM introduces a high-throughput approach to expansion microscopy by adapting the technique to 96-well plates, significantly increasing scalability compared to traditional slide-based ExM. The use of photoinitiation with Irgacure 2959 ensures consistent gel formation and expansion, overcoming limitations of APS/TEMED polymerization. This method is compatible with autonomous imaging systems, enabling rapid data acquisition and analysis of thousands of cells, which is a substantial improvement over previous ExM variants.

title: Analyzing Centrioles and Cilia by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Dong Kong, Jadranka Loncarek
summary: Fig 1: U2OS cells were expanded and imaged to reveal centrioles and cilia structures, highlighting the method's ability to enhance visualization. Fig 2: Immunostaining of acetylated tubulin and DAPI labeling demonstrated the technique's effectiveness in identifying microtubule structures and chromosomal arrangements. Fig 3: The expansion microscopy method was validated by comparing resolution improvements with conventional microscopy, emphasizing its potential for detailed cellular analysis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of centrioles and cilia in U2OS cells, providing insights into cellular structures that are challenging to resolve with conventional microscopy techniques.
novelty: This study presents a significant advancement in expansion microscopy by applying it to human U2OS cells, achieving a 4x expansion factor. The method allows for submicron resolution, surpassing traditional microscopy limits and offering new opportunities for cellular and molecular biology research. The use of PFA + AA as an anchoring reagent is highlighted as a key component in maintaining structural integrity during expansion.

title: Nanopore Long Read DNA Sequencing of Protozoan Parasites: Hybrid Genome Assembly of Trypanosoma cruzi
authors: Florencia Díaz-Viraque, Gonzalo Greif, Luisa Berná, Carlos Robello
summary: Fig 1: Describes the challenges of assembling Trypanosoma cruzi genomes due to repetitive sequences and introduces the hybrid assembly approach. Fig 2: Details the protocol for high molecular weight DNA extraction and library preparation for sequencing. Fig 3: Explains the computational analysis steps for genome assembly, including base-calling and assembly polishing. Fig 4: Discusses the results of using hybrid assembly strategies to improve genome completeness and accuracy.
application_goal: The protocol enables the assembly of highly repetitive and complex genomes of protozoan parasites by combining long-read and short-read sequencing technologies, improving genome completeness and accuracy.
novelty: This work demonstrates the effectiveness of hybrid genome assembly strategies using long-read technologies like Oxford Nanopore and short-read technologies like Illumina. The approach addresses the challenges posed by repetitive sequences in Trypanosoma cruzi genomes, offering a significant improvement over previous methods that relied solely on short reads. The protocol's adaptability to other protozoan parasites highlights its potential for broad application in genomic studies.

title: C. elegans: Methods and Applications, Third Edition
authors: Gal Haspel, Anne C. Hart
summary: Fig 1: Provides practical advice for setting up a C. elegans research lab, emphasizing community resources and organization. Fig 2: Discusses the basics of setting up teaching labs with C. elegans, focusing on equipment and inclusive teaching practices. Fig 3: Describes a teaching lab module for understanding gene-behavior connections using C. elegans chemotaxis assays.
application_goal: The protocol enables the establishment of C. elegans research and teaching labs, providing a framework for understanding gene function through behavioral assays.
novelty: This work compiles comprehensive resources and practical advice for setting up C. elegans labs, emphasizing community engagement and inclusive teaching. It does not introduce new chemistry or microscopy techniques but provides a structured approach to using C. elegans in research and education.

title: Expansion Microscopy of Bacillus subtilis
authors: Viola Middelhauve, Jan Peter Siebrasse, Ulrich Kubitscheck
summary: Fig 1: Describes the use of expansion microscopy to visualize Bacillus subtilis, highlighting its potential to enhance resolution without sophisticated equipment. Fig 2: Demonstrates the application of the method to observe bacterial cell wall structures, emphasizing its utility in studying bacterial morphology. Fig 3: Shows the integration of expansion microscopy with fluorescence techniques to track changes in membrane fluidity, underscoring its versatility in biological research.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of Bacillus subtilis at a super-resolved level, allowing researchers to study bacterial cell wall structures and membrane dynamics with enhanced clarity and detail.
novelty: This work introduces the application of expansion microscopy to Bacillus subtilis, providing a cost-effective alternative to traditional super-resolution methods. By expanding the bacterial cells, researchers can achieve high-resolution imaging without the need for advanced optical instruments. This approach opens new avenues for studying bacterial morphology and physiology, offering insights that were previously inaccessible with conventional microscopy techniques.

title: Quantiﬁcation of Microtubule-Bundling Activity of MAPs Using TIRF Microscopy
authors: Sharol Schmidt-Marcec, Austin Ross, Andrei Smertenko
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the method for quantifying microtubule-bundling using TIRF microscopy. Fig 2 shows the impact of different concentrations of MACET4 on microtubule-bundling, highlighting the importance of concentration in avoiding artificial aggregation. Fig 3 illustrates the different types of microtubule-microtubule interactions, emphasizing the distinct effects of MACET4 and MAP65 on microtubule alignment.
application_goal: The protocol enables the quantification of microtubule-bundling activity of MAPs in vitro, allowing for the comparison of different MAPs and the modeling of their contribution to microtubule array organization and dynamics.
novelty: This work provides a sensitive method for measuring microtubule-bundling using stable red and green microtubules, which can distinguish between different types of microtubule-microtubule interactions. This approach allows for a detailed assessment of microtubule-bundling activity, which is crucial for understanding the physiological relevance of MAPs and their role in microtubule array construction.

title: Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy (U-ExM) of the Fission Yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe
authors: Felix Mikus, Gautam Dey
summary: Fig 1: Describes the dual luciferase reporter assay in Schizosaccharomyces pombe, highlighting the generation of a reporter plasmid construct. Fig 2: Details the high-throughput measurement of single-fission yeast cell volume using fluorescence exclusion. Fig 3: Explains the use of machine learning to measure cell dimensions in fission yeast. Fig 4: Introduces Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy (U-ExM) for visualizing fission yeast. Fig 5: Demonstrates live imaging of fission yeast single-cell lineages using a microfluidic device.
application_goal: The protocol enables detailed visualization and analysis of fission yeast at a cellular level, facilitating studies on cell structure and function.
novelty: This work introduces new methods for microscopy and imaging in fission yeast, including the use of Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy (U-ExM). It provides a comprehensive set of protocols that capture the latest developments in yeast techniques, offering advancements over previous methods by incorporating recent technologies such as CRISPR/Cas9 and bioinformatics.

title: Super-resolution Analysis of Astrocyte Morphology Using Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gerald Seifert, Erik Sommer, Stefan Passlick, Christian Henneberger
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the application of immunostaining across various mammalian species, highlighting the versatility of the protocol. Fig 2 showcases double immunostaining on prefrontal cortex specimens, emphasizing the method's ability to label multiple proteins simultaneously. The figures illustrate the protocol's effectiveness in achieving high signal-to-noise ratios even in challenging tissue conditions.
application_goal: The protocol enables the visualization of astrocyte morphology with high specificity and resolution across a wide range of mammalian species, facilitating comparative studies in neurobiology.
novelty: This work presents a versatile immunofluorescence protocol applicable to both model and non-model mammalian species, addressing the limitations of conventional methods that often fail with non-perfused or over-fixed tissues. The protocol's adaptability to various tissue preparation methods and its ability to achieve high-resolution imaging of astrocytes mark a significant advancement in the field.

title: Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy for the Analysis of Trypanosoma cruzi Infection
authors: Felipe Castro Capurro, Victoria Lucia Alonso
summary: Fig 1: Computer-aided drug discovery methods are described for Chagas disease, highlighting their role in identifying new pharmacological targets. Fig 2: Chromatin interaction maps of Trypanosoma cruzi are presented, providing insights into genomic organization. Fig 3: A genome-wide GC composition tool is introduced for unbiased assessment of Trypanosoma cruzi genomic compartments. Fig 4: An algorithm for annotation of Trypanosoma cruzi MASP sequences is detailed, aiding in genomic studies.
application_goal: The protocol enables the detailed analysis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection using advanced microscopy techniques, providing insights into the ultrastructural changes during infection.
novelty: This work compiles cutting-edge protocols for studying Trypanosoma cruzi, integrating bioinformatics, biochemical, genetic, and cell biology techniques. It provides a comprehensive understanding of the parasite's biology and its interaction with the host immune response, which is crucial for improving Chagas disease diagnosis and treatment. The integration of in silico methods in drug discovery is particularly novel, offering cost-effective solutions for low- and middle-income countries.

title: High-Resolution Imaging Mass Spectrometry of Human Donor Eye: Photoreceptors Cells and Basal Laminar Deposit of Age-Related Macular Degeneration
authors: David M. G. Anderson, Ankita Kotnala, Jeffrey D. Messinger, Nathan Heath Patterson, Jeffrey M. Spraggins, Christine A. Curcio, Richard M. Caprioli, Kevin L. Schey
summary: Fig 1: MALDI IMS was used to localize molecular species in photoreceptor cells and basal laminar deposits, providing insights into AMD pathology. Fig 2: High-resolution imaging identified specific lipids in BLamD, correlating with clinical OCT findings and enhancing understanding of lipid accumulation in AMD.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the localization and identification of molecular species in retinal tissues, particularly in photoreceptor cells and basal laminar deposits, which are crucial for understanding the molecular processes in age-related macular degeneration.
novelty: This study utilizes MALDI IMS combined with multimodal imaging to achieve cellular resolution in identifying molecular species in retinal tissues. The approach provides a comprehensive method for studying the molecular composition of photoreceptor cells and basal laminar deposits, offering new insights into AMD pathology compared to traditional histochemical and chromatography methods.

title: A highly homogeneous polymer composed of tetrahedron-like monomers for high-isotropy expansion microscopy
authors: Ruixuan Gao, Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Linyi Gao, Kiryl D. Piatkevich, Rachael L. Neve, James B. Munro, Srigokul Upadhyayula, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Design of tetra-gel monomers and their assembly via click-chemistry for improved hydrogel homogeneity. Fig 2: Application of tetra-gel ExM to cells and tissues, demonstrating enhanced resolution and fluorescence retention. Fig 3: Iterative expansion using tetra-gel, showing improved structural preservation in expanded HeLa cells. Fig 4: Comparison of spatial errors in HSV-1 virions expanded with tetra-gel versus PAAG, highlighting reduced errors with tetra-gel. Fig 5: Shape analysis of expanded virions, showing better preservation of spherical shape with tetra-gel.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale structures with reduced spatial errors and improved isotropy, allowing for more accurate imaging of biological specimens at the molecular level.
novelty: This study introduces a new type of hydrogel, the tetra-gel, which is assembled via non-radical step-growth polymerization, offering a more homogeneous network structure compared to traditional PAAG-based ExM. The tetra-gel reduces spatial errors and better preserves the morphology of expanded specimens, achieving a median spatial error of 9.2 nm compared to 14.3 nm with PAAG. This advancement points towards achieving single-biomolecule accuracy in ExM, setting a new standard for expansion microscopy techniques.
source_file: A highly homogeneous polymer composed of tetrahedron-like monomers for high-isotropy expansion microscopy.pdf

title: A practical guide to optimization in X10 expansion microscopy
authors: Sven Truckenbrodt, Christoph Sommer, Silvio O. Rizzoli, Johann G. Danzl
summary: Fig 1: Overview of the X10 expansion microscopy protocol, highlighting the seven stages from labeling to validation. Fig 2: Demonstrates the effect of anchoring and digestion conditions on sample integrity and expansion. Fig 3: Illustrates the assembly of a gelation chamber for polymerization. Fig 4: Shows the removal of the gel from the gelation chamber and preparation for digestion. Fig 5: Depicts the expansion process of the gel in ddH2O. Fig 6: Details the assembly of an imaging chamber for post-expansion imaging.
application_goal: This protocol enables researchers to perform X10 expansion microscopy, achieving a tenfold expansion and a resolution of ~25 nm, using standard fluorescence microscopes. It provides detailed steps for optimizing each stage of the process, from immunostaining to imaging, ensuring reproducibility and high-quality results.
novelty: X10 expansion microscopy represents a significant advancement over the classic fourfold expansion microscopy by achieving a tenfold expansion in a single step, using a novel gel chemistry. This method provides a higher resolution of ~25 nm, compared to the ~70 nm resolution of the original method. The protocol also introduces optimizations for anchoring and homogenization, improving sample integrity and reducing distortions during expansion.
source_file: A practical guide to optimization in X10 expansion microscopy.pdf

title: A three-dimensional single-cell-resolution whole-brain atlas using CUBIC-X expansion microscopy and tissue clearing
authors: Tatsuya C. Murakami, Tomoyuki Mano, Shu Saikawa, Shuhei A. Horiguchi, Daichi Shigeta, Kousuke Baba, Hiroshi Sekiya, Yoshihiro Shimizu, Kenji F. Tanaka, Hiroshi Kiyonari, Masamitsu Iino, Hideki Mochizuki, Kazuki Tainaka, Hiroki R. Ueda
summary: Fig 1: Identified swelling reagents for tissue expansion. Fig 2: Developed CUBIC-X protocol for whole-brain expansion and clearing. Fig 3: Demonstrated whole-brain imaging with customized LSFM. Fig 4: Constructed CUBIC-Atlas for single-cell-resolution brain mapping. Fig 5: Applied CUBIC-Atlas for developmental cell profiling. Fig 6: Revealed cell number changes in brain regions during development. Fig 7: Used CUBIC-Atlas for probabilistic mapping of brain activity.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the construction of a single-cell-resolution mouse brain atlas, facilitating comprehensive analysis of cellular circuits and brain functions.
novelty: This study introduces CUBIC-X, a novel expansion microscopy protocol that allows for whole-organ expansion while retaining fluorescent proteins, unlike previous methods that required tissue sectioning or special anchoring matrices. The CUBIC-X protocol achieves a 10x expansion, providing subcellular resolution and enabling the construction of a single-cell-resolution brain atlas. This work advances the field by offering a new platform for whole-brain cell profiling and functional mapping, surpassing the limitations of previous expansion microscopy techniques.
source_file: A three-dimensional single-cell-resolution whole-brain atlas using CUBIC-X expansion microscopy and tissue clearing.pdf

title: Expansion Microscopy with Multifunctional Polymer Dots
authors: Jie Liu, Xiaofeng Fang, Zhihe Liu, Rongqin Li, Yicheng Yang, Yujie Sun, Zhongying Zhao, Changfeng Wu
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the design of multifunctional Pdots for ExM, highlighting their ability to target, anchor, and report fluorescence. Fig 2: Shows high-fidelity imaging of microtubules and neuron synapses using Pdots, emphasizing resolution enhancement. Fig 3: Illustrates Ex-SOFI nanoscopy, achieving ≈30 nm resolution, showcasing the potential of Pdots in super-resolution imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of subcellular structures and neuron synapses with high brightness and resolution, overcoming challenges of fluorophore degradation and dilution in ExM.
novelty: This study introduces multifunctional polymer dots (Pdots) that significantly enhance fluorescence brightness and resolution in ExM. Compared to previous ExM variants, the Pdots provide a 3-6 times higher signal-to-background ratio than Alexa dyes and enable ≈30 nm resolution when combined with SOFI. The use of methacrymide for direct gel anchoring is a novel approach that improves fluorophore retention and labeling efficiency.
source_file: Advanced Materials - 2021 - Liu - Expansion Microscopy with Multifunctional Polymer Dots.pdf

title: In Situ Super-Resolution Imaging of Organoids and Extracellular Matrix Interactions via Phototransfer by Allyl Sulfide Exchange-Expansion Microscopy (PhASE-ExM)
authors: Michael R. Blatchley, Kemal Arda Günay, F. Max Yavitt, Elijah M. Hawat, Peter J. Dempsey, Kristi S. Anseth
summary: Fig 1: PhASE-ExM combines allyl sulfide crosslinking with photoexpansion microscopy for rapid hydrogel formation and expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrates super-resolution imaging of organoids in Matrigel, highlighting improved imaging depth and resolution. Fig 3: Examines cell-ECM interactions in organoids, showing spatial heterogeneity in collagen IV and integrin β1 interactions. Fig 4: PhASE-ExM applied to PEG-AlS hydrogels reveals cell-secreted ECM protein localization and dynamics during organoid differentiation.
application_goal: The protocol enables super-resolution imaging of organoids and their extracellular matrix in 3D, overcoming limitations of light scattering and absorption in traditional imaging methods. It allows for detailed visualization of cell-ECM interactions and protein localization, crucial for understanding organoid growth and differentiation.
novelty: PhASE-ExM introduces a novel combination of allyl sulfide crosslinking and photoexpansion microscopy, enabling rapid hydrogel formation and expansion. Compared to previous ExM techniques, it offers faster processing times and improved resolution. The method is particularly advantageous for imaging organoids in synthetic hydrogels, allowing for detailed study of cell-ECM interactions and ECM protein dynamics, which were previously challenging due to limitations in imaging depth and resolution.
source_file: Advanced Materials - 2022 - Blatchley - In Situ Super‐Resolution Imaging of Organoids and Extracellular Matrix Interactions.pdf

title: MicroMagnify: A Multiplexed Expansion Microscopy Method for Pathogens and Infected Tissues
authors: Zhangyu Cheng, Caroline Stefani, Thomas Skillman, Aleksandra Klimas, Aramchan Lee, Emma F. DiBernardo, Karina Mueller Brown, Tatyana Milman, Yuhong Wang, Brendan R. Gallagher, Katherine Lagree, Bhanu P. Jena, Jose S. Pulido, Scott G. Filler, Aaron P. Mitchell, N. Luisa Hiller, Adam Lacy-Hulbert, Yongxin Zhao
summary: Fig 1: μMagnify combines heat denaturation and enzyme cocktails for cell wall digestion, enabling expansion of microbial cells with minimal distortion. Fig 2: Demonstrates nanoscale imaging of microbial cell morphology and intracellular organelles, revealing fine structures like nucleus envelope and mitochondria. Fig 3: Expands formalin-fixed mouse tongue tissue, preserving protein epitopes and revealing detailed molecular structures. Fig 4: Enables 3D characterization of pathogen-infected cornea samples, distinguishing different pathogens with lectin stains. Fig 5: Achieves ten-color multiplexed imaging of S. aureus-infected U2OS cells, allowing study of protein-protein interactions.
application_goal: The protocol enables high-plex fluorescence imaging of pathogen and infected samples, allowing for detailed study of pathogen-host interactions and potential new diagnostic methods for infectious diseases.
novelty: μMagnify advances expansion microscopy by enabling the expansion of a wide range of pathogen-infected samples, including formalin-fixed tissues, with minimal distortion. It combines heat denaturation with enzyme cocktails for effective cell wall digestion, overcoming limitations of previous methods that struggled with microbial imaging. The method achieves up to eightfold expansion, providing resolution comparable to traditional super-resolution techniques, and allows for multiplexed imaging of diverse biomolecules, expanding the scope of microbiology research.
source_file: Advanced Science - 2023 - Cheng - MicroMagnify  A Multiplexed Expansion Microscopy Method for Pathogens and Infected.pdf
