title: Molecular resolution imaging by post-labeling expansion single-molecule localization microscopy (Ex-SMLM)
authors: Fabian U. Zwettler, Sebastian Reinhard, Davide Gambarotto, Toby D. M. Bell, Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the use of post-labeling Ex-SMLM to preserve ultrastructural details of microtubules, improving labeling efficiency. Fig 2: Compares pre- and post-labeling methods, showing reduced linkage error with post-labeling. Fig 3: Highlights the use of re-embedding to enable Ex-SMLM in photoswitching buffer, achieving high spatial resolution. Fig 4: Applies Ex-SMLM to centrioles, resolving their 9-fold symmetry and microtubule triplets.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of ultrastructural details of microtubules and centrioles with molecular resolution, overcoming previous limitations in labeling efficiency and linkage error.
novelty: This study introduces a post-labeling Ex-SMLM approach that significantly reduces linkage error and improves labeling efficiency compared to previous ExM variants. The re-embedding strategy allows for the use of standard photoswitching buffers, enabling dSTORM imaging of expanded samples with sub-10-nm resolution, bridging the gap to electron microscopy.
source_file: Molecular resolution imaging by post-labeling expansion single-molecule localization microscopy (Ex-SMLM).pdf

title: Multiplexed and scalable super-resolution imaging of three-dimensional protein localization in size-adjustable tissues
authors: Taeyun Ku, Justin Swaney, Jeong-Yoon Park, Alexandre Albanese, Evan Murray, Jae Hun Cho, Young-Gyun Park, Vamsi Mangena, Jiapei Chen, Kwanghun Chung
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the chemistry of hydrogel-tissue hybridization and its effect on tissue expansion. Fig 2 shows the preservation of multiscale architectures and super-resolution imaging capabilities of MAP. Fig 3 highlights the compatibility of MAP with a wide range of antibodies for proteomic imaging. Fig 4 illustrates the potential for highly multiplexed immunolabeling using MAP. Fig 5 explores the preservation of intercellular connectivity and accurate tracing of neural fibers. Fig 6 demonstrates the applicability of MAP for imaging thick tissues with uniform staining.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the preservation and expansion of intact tissues for super-resolution imaging, allowing for detailed visualization of protein localization and cellular architectures across large tissue volumes.
novelty: This work introduces MAP, a method that achieves super-resolution imaging of intact tissues by preventing intra- and interprotein crosslinking during hydrogel-tissue hybridization. Unlike previous ExM variants, MAP preserves protein content and organ-scale connectivity, enabling multiscale imaging without the need for protease treatment. The method is compatible with a wide range of antibodies, facilitating detailed proteomic analysis. MAP's ability to reversibly modulate tissue size offers a unique advantage for capturing both global and local tissue architectures.
source_file: Multiplexed and scalable super-resolution imaging of three-dimensional protein localization in size-adjustable tissues.pdf

title: Multiplexed imaging of high-density libraries of RNAs with MERFISH and expansion microscopy
authors: Guiping Wang, Jeffrey R. Moffitt, Xiaowei Zhuang
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated the effect of RNA density on MERFISH detection efficiency, showing reduced efficiency in high-density samples. Fig 2: Showed that expansion microscopy improves RNA detection efficiency in high-density samples by increasing molecular separation. Fig 3: Combined MERFISH with immunofluorescence to visualize proteins and RNAs simultaneously, providing cellular context for RNA expression analysis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the accurate identification and counting of RNAs in high-density libraries, overcoming limitations of signal overlap in traditional MERFISH by using expansion microscopy to increase molecular separation.
novelty: This study combines MERFISH with expansion microscopy to address the challenge of high RNA density, achieving near 100% detection efficiency in expanded samples. Unlike previous methods, this approach anchors RNAs via poly(A) tails, allowing for effective separation without stretching. The integration with immunofluorescence further enhances the method's versatility, enabling simultaneous transcriptomic and proteomic analysis.
source_file: Multiplexed imaging of high-density libraries of RNAs with MERFISH and expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Nanoscale imaging of bacterial infections by sphingolipid expansion microscopy
authors: Ralph Götz, Tobias C. Kunz, Julian Fink, Franziska Solger, Jan Schlegel, Jürgen Seibel, Vera Kozjak-Pavlovic, Thomas Rudel, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the synthesis and incorporation of α-NH2-ω-N3-C6-ceramide into cellular membranes, enabling fixation and fluorescence labeling. Fig 2 shows super-resolution imaging of cellular membranes and protein interactions using sphingolipid ExM. Fig 3 visualizes intracellular pathogens and their interactions with mitochondrial proteins, highlighting the utility of sphingolipid ExM in infection studies. Fig 4 reveals the incorporation of ceramides into bacterial membranes, achieving nanoscale resolution to distinguish between outer and inner membranes.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of sphingolipid-protein interactions and bacterial infections at nanoscale resolution, providing insights into membrane organization and pathogen-host interactions.
novelty: This study introduces a novel sphingolipid ExM approach that allows for the expansion and imaging of lipid membranes, which were previously inaccessible due to the lack of primary amino groups. The use of α-NH2-ω-N3-C6-ceramide enables the fixation and labeling of lipids, achieving a resolution of 10-20 nm, comparable to electron microscopy. This method expands the capabilities of ExM beyond proteins and nucleic acids, offering new opportunities for studying lipid-protein interactions and bacterial infections.
source_file: Nanoscale imaging of bacterial infections by sphingolipid expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Nanoscale imaging of clinical specimens using conventional and rapid-expansion pathology
authors: Octavian Bucur, Feifei Fu, Mike Calderon, Geetha H. Mylvaganam, Ngoc L. Ly, Jimmy Day, Simon Watkin, Bruce D. Walker, Edward S. Boyden, Yongxin Zhao
summary: Fig 1: ExPath and rExPath workflows are outlined for processing clinical specimens, enabling rapid imaging. Fig 2: Validation of ExPath and rExPath shows low distortion and high resolution in expanded tissues. Fig 3: Comparison of ExPath and rExPath on prostate tissue demonstrates similar image quality. Fig 4: ExPath reduces tissue autofluorescence, enhancing imaging clarity. Fig 5: ExPath is applied to a variety of human tissues, showing its versatility. Fig 6: rExPath is used to image lymph node specimens, highlighting its rapid processing capability.
application_goal: The protocol enables the expansion of human tissues, allowing nanoscale resolution imaging using conventional microscopes. This facilitates detailed analysis of clinical specimens, which is crucial for both research and diagnostic purposes.
novelty: This study introduces a rapid variant of expansion pathology (rExPath) that significantly reduces processing time for thin tissue sections, making it feasible for potential clinical applications. Compared to previous ExM variants, rExPath maintains low distortion and high resolution while enabling faster processing. The use of sodium acrylate and acrylamide in the polymer matrix, along with a strong proteolytic digestion step, distinguishes this method from other super-resolution techniques that require specialized equipment.
source_file: Nanoscale imaging of clinical specimens using conventional and rapid-expansion pathology.pdf

title: Geometry-preserving expansion microscopy microplates enable high-fidelity nanoscale distortion mapping
authors: Rajpinder S. Seehra, Samantha J. Warrington, Benjamin H.K. Allouis, Thomas M.D. Sheard, Michael E. Spencer, Tayla Shakespeare, Ashley Cadby, Daniel Bose, David Strutt, Izzy Jayasinghe
sample: dissected pupal Drosophila melanogaster wing tissue
summary: Fig 1: Developed a 3D-printable microplate system for ExM to preserve gel geometry and enable in situ imaging. Fig 2: Demonstrated pre- and post-ExM imaging of HeLa cells and Drosophila wing tissue, revealing distortion-prone structures. Fig 3: Showcased two-color imaging and distortion analysis in HeLa cells and fly wing tissue, highlighting the utility of multiplexed staining. The study emphasizes the importance of pre- and post-ExM imaging for accurate distortion assessment.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-fidelity nanoscale distortion mapping by preserving gel geometry during expansion, allowing for accurate pre- and post-ExM imaging. This approach facilitates the study of distortion-prone structures in both cellular and tissue samples, enhancing the reliability of ExM data.
novelty: This study introduces a novel 3D-printable microplate system that preserves gel geometry during expansion, addressing the challenge of manual handling in ExM. Unlike previous ExM variants, this method allows for in situ imaging, reducing distortion and improving reproducibility. The integration of multiplexed staining further enhances the versatility of ExM, enabling detailed distortion analysis across different sample types.

title: Expansion microscopy of neutrophil nuclear structure and extracellular traps
authors: Jason Scott Holsapple, Lena Schnitzler, Louisa Rusch, Tobias Horst Baldeweg, Elsa Neubert, Sebastian Kruss, Luise Erpenbeck
summary: Fig 1: Developed a method for expansion microscopy of neutrophils, achieving isotropic expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrated isotropy and expansion factor of 4.9x for neutrophil nuclei and NETs. Fig 3: Showed increased resolution and spatial information of chromatin and nuclear proteins. Fig 4: Quantified colocalization improvements with expansion microscopy. Fig 5: Identified histone-rich domains in NETotic cells, revealing granularity. Fig 6: Validated expansion microscopy for various neutrophil structures, including MPO and lamins. Fig 7: Revealed punctate NPM1 agglomerations in the nucleus.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolved imaging of neutrophil nuclear structures and extracellular traps, providing detailed insights into chromatin and protein distribution during NETosis. This method allows for the visualization of fragile and complex cellular structures with improved resolution, facilitating a better understanding of neutrophil biology and immune functions.
novelty: This study presents a novel application of expansion microscopy to human neutrophils, achieving a resolution improvement to <40–50 nm without the need for complex optical systems. Compared to prior ExM variants, this method provides a cost-effective and accessible approach to super-resolution imaging of immune cells. The study highlights the ability to visualize nuclear and cytoplasmic structures with high detail, revealing new insights into chromatin organization and protein localization during NETosis.

title: Accelerated protein retention expansion microscopy using microwave radiation
authors: Meghan R. Bullard, Juan Carlos Martinez-Cervantes, Norisha B. Quaicoe, Amanda Jin, Danya A. Adams, Jessica M. Lin, Elena Iliadis, Tess M. Seidler, Isaac Cervantes-Sandoval, Hai-yan He
summary: Fig 1: M/WExM protocol accelerates ExM in X. laevis and D. melanogaster brain tissue, reducing processing time significantly. Fig 2: M/WExM maintains resolution and signal-to-noise ratio, demonstrating effective protein retention. Fig 3: M/WExM preserves nuclei morphology, confirming isotropic expansion. Fig 4: M/WExM increases expansion magnitude, suggesting M/W radiation facilitates expansion. Fig 5: M/WExM resolves synaptic components, maintaining ExM's superior resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled a significant reduction in processing time for expansion microscopy, from days to hours, while maintaining the high resolution and signal-to-noise ratio of the original ExM protocol. This efficiency gain allows for more rapid and consistent imaging of subcellular structures in various biological tissues.
novelty: This study introduces a microwave-assisted ExM protocol (M/WExM) that significantly accelerates the traditional ExM process without compromising resolution or tissue integrity. Compared to prior ExM variants, M/WExM offers a higher expansion factor and reduced processing time, leveraging microwave radiation to enhance diffusion and expansion. This approach is novel in its application to both Xenopus and Drosophila brain tissues, demonstrating versatility across different model organisms.

title: Expansion microscopy reveals nano-scale insights into the human neuromuscular junction
authors: Abdullah Ramadan, Thomas M.D. Sheard, Abrar Alhindi, Philippa A. Rust, Ross A. Jones, Izzy Jayasinghe, Thomas H. Gillingwater
summary: Fig 1: ExM reveals detailed AChR and SV2 distribution in human and mouse NMJs, highlighting species-specific differences. Fig 2: Quantitative analysis shows a 4x expansion factor, confirming ExM's ability to enhance NMJ imaging. Fig 3: ExM provides superior resolution of NMJ ultrastructure compared to standard confocal microscopy. Fig 4: Deconvolution techniques improve image clarity, facilitating detailed structural analysis. Fig 5: Quantitative analysis of AChR stripes reveals significant differences between human and mouse NMJs.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of neuromuscular junctions in human and mouse tissues, revealing species-specific differences in synaptic architecture and providing a cost-effective alternative to super-resolution microscopy.
novelty: This study demonstrates the adaptation of expansion microscopy for use with human neuromuscular junctions, offering a novel approach to achieve nano-scale resolution without the need for specialized super-resolution equipment. The work highlights the ability of ExM to reveal detailed structural differences between human and mouse NMJs, which were previously difficult to assess due to the limitations of traditional microscopy techniques. The use of a 4x expansion factor and the application of ExM to whole-mount muscle biopsy samples represent significant advancements in the field, providing new insights into the spatial organization of synaptic components.

title: Photo-expansion microscopy enables super-resolution imaging of cells embedded in 3D hydrogels
authors: Kemal Arda Günay, Tze-Ling Chang, Nathaniel P. Skillin, Varsha V. Rao, Laura J. Macdougall, Alicia A. Cutler, Jason S. Silver, Tobin E. Brown, Chi Zhang, Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Bradley B. Olwin, Edward S. Boyden, Kristi S. Anseth
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the PhotoExM process and its ability to decouple monomer diffusion from polymerization, enhancing expansion isotropy. Fig 2: Validates the isotropy and resolution of PhotoExM using C2C12 cells and mouse muscle tissue, achieving <120 nm resolution. Fig 3: Shows super-resolution imaging of hMSCs in 3D hydrogels, revealing fibronectin deposition and focal adhesion formation. Fig 4: Examines nuclear deformation and MT-MMP1 activity in hMSCs, highlighting cell-surface metalloproteinase roles in matrix remodeling.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of cells embedded within 3D hydrogels, allowing for detailed visualization of cell-matrix interactions and cellular processes at nanoscale resolution. This advancement facilitates the study of cellular behavior in biomimetic environments, providing insights into focal adhesion maturation and matrix remodeling.
novelty: This study introduces PhotoExM, a novel expansion microscopy technique that utilizes photoinitiated polymerization to achieve rapid and uniform expansion of biological samples, including those embedded in 3D hydrogels. Compared to traditional ExM methods, PhotoExM offers faster polymerization kinetics and improved mechanical properties, enabling high-resolution imaging without the need for an inert atmosphere. The technique's ability to decouple monomer diffusion from polymerization is particularly advantageous for imaging complex 3D structures, providing a significant advancement over previous ExM variants.
source_file: Photo-expansion microscopy enables super-resolution imaging of cells embedded in 3D hydrogels.pdf

title: Quantifying Expansion Microscopy with DNA Origami Expansion Nanorulers
authors: Max B. Scheible, Philip Tinnefeld
summary: Fig 1: DNA nanorulers are modified for crosslinking to a polymer network, enabling expansion and imaging below the diffraction limit. Fig 2: The expansion factor is quantified by comparing pre- and post-expansion distances, showing a macroscopic expansion factor of 3.6. Fig 3: Microscopic expansion factor is determined using GATTAnalysis software, revealing a factor of 2.8 and highlighting deviations from macroscopic measurements.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the quantification of expansion microscopy by using DNA origami nanorulers as a standard to measure the microscopic expansion factor, providing insights into the homogeneity and isotropy of the expansion process.
novelty: This work introduces DNA origami nanorulers as a novel tool for quantifying expansion in expansion microscopy, addressing the challenge of correlating macroscopic and microscopic expansion factors. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach provides a quantitative standard for measuring expansion, revealing deviations between macroscopic and microscopic factors and offering a method to assess the homogeneity of expansion. The use of DNA nanotechnology in this context is a significant advancement, providing a new way to evaluate the effectiveness and limitations of expansion microscopy techniques.
source_file: Quantifying Expansion Microscopy with DNA Origami Expansion Nanorulers.pdf

title: Quantitative expansion microscopy for the characterization of the spectrin periodic skeleton of axons using fluorescence microscopy
authors: Gaby F. Martínez, Nahir G. Gazal, Gonzalo Quassollo, Alan M. Szalai, Esther Del Cid-Pellitero, Thomas M. Durcan, Edward A. Fon, Mariano Bisbal, Fernando D. Stefani, Nicolas Unsain

model_system: mouse dorsal root ganglion sensory neurons

summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates that gels with proteins expand more than gels alone, highlighting the importance of accurate expansion factor estimation. Fig 2: Shows that ExM reveals the periodic distribution of βII-spectrin in axons, validating the method against STED microscopy. Fig 3: Illustrates the 3D and multicolor capabilities of ExM, allowing detailed visualization of the MPS. Fig 4: Compares ExM and STED, showing similar periodic structures in axons, confirming ExM's accuracy in studying the MPS.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the quantitative study of the membrane-associated periodic skeleton (MPS) in cultured neurons using conventional microscopes, facilitating the study of this structure in neurobiology laboratories.
novelty: This study presents a calibrated expansion microscopy protocol that allows for the quantitative examination of the MPS, a structure previously only visualized with high-end super-resolution techniques like STED. The work highlights the importance of accurate expansion factor estimation, showing that protein-containing gels expand more than gels alone. This approach provides a simpler, more accessible method for studying the MPS, with comparable results to STED, making it a valuable tool for neurobiology research.
source_file: Quantitative expansion microscopy for the characterization of the spectrin periodic skeleton of axons using fluorescence microscopy.pdf

title: Revealing nanostructures in brain tissue via protein decrowding by iterative expansion microscopy
authors: Deblina Sarkar, Jinyoung Kang, Asmamaw T. Wassie, Margaret E. Schroeder, Zhuyu Peng, Tyler B. Tarr, Ai-Hui Tang, Emily D. Niederst, Jennie Z. Young, Hanquan Su, Demian Park, Peng Yin, Li-Huei Tsai, Thomas A. Blanpied, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: ExR technology decrowds proteins for enhanced imaging. Fig 2: ExR achieves ~20 nm resolution, comparable to DNA-PAINT. Fig 3: ExR reveals synaptic nanostructures not visible pre-expansion. Fig 4: ExR shows calcium channels in synaptic nanocolumns. Fig 5: ExR uncovers periodic amyloid nanostructures in Alzheimer's model. Fig 6: ExR reveals co-localization of amyloid and ion channels.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of previously inaccessible nanostructures in brain tissue, revealing detailed synaptic architecture and amyloid formations in Alzheimer's models.
novelty: ExR combines iterative expansion with protein decrowding, achieving 20 nm resolution comparable to DNA-PAINT. It reveals previously unseen structures, such as synaptic nanocolumns and periodic amyloid formations, surpassing prior ExM variants in resolution and applicability to dense tissues.
source_file: Revealing nanostructures in brain tissue via protein decrowding by iterative expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Visualization of the intracellular structures of bacteria using expansion microscopy
authors: N A Rumyantseva, A D Vedyaykin, I E Vishnyakov, M A Khodorkovskii
summary: Fig 1 shows micrographs of E. coli cells before and after expansion, highlighting the effectiveness of proteinase K digestion. Fig 2 demonstrates the preservation of the Z-ring structure under specific fixation and cleavage conditions, emphasizing the importance of sample preparation. Fig 3 reveals uneven DNA expansion, suggesting the need for further protocol optimization to maintain DNA structure integrity.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of FtsZ structures in E. coli cells with significantly higher resolution than conventional fluorescence microscopy, allowing detailed analysis of protein localization within the cell.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of expansion microscopy (ExM) to visualize bacterial intracellular structures with enhanced resolution, achieving approximately 60 nm. Unlike traditional super-resolution methods, ExM does not require complex optical equipment, making it accessible for broader use. The study highlights the importance of optimizing sample preparation, particularly proteolytic cleavage, to achieve effective expansion and preservation of cellular structures. This work contributes to the field by providing insights into the structural organization of bacterial cells, which are challenging to study due to their small size.

title: Applying the Expansion Microscopy Method in Neurobiology
authors: K. Z. Derevtsova, E. I. Pchitskaya, A. V. Rakovskaya, I. B. Bezprozvanny
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the polymerization chamber setup for embedding brain sections in a gel. Fig 2 shows the preparation of brain slices for polymerization, highlighting the importance of precise alignment. Fig 3 illustrates the handling of gel samples to prevent breakage during expansion. Fig 4 compares the size of brain slices before and after expansion, showcasing the 4.5x increase. Fig 5 and 6 present confocal images of neurons before and after expansion, emphasizing the enhanced visualization of dendritic spines. Fig 7 and 8 display two-color micrographs of neurons, highlighting the successful retention of fluorescence post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale structures and complexes, such as individual cell organelles, using a conventional microscope. It allowed for the study of the colocalization of regulatory molecules and the nature of intersynaptic contacts between nerve cells on expanded samples. The optical transparency of the samples facilitated tracing the three-dimensional structure of neurons, improving the quality of analysis.
novelty: This study presents an adapted ExM protocol that reduces the destructive effect of proteinases on immunoglobulins, preserving the signal of endogenously synthesized fluorophores. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach maintains fluorescence intensity while achieving a 4.5x expansion, enabling detailed visualization of neuronal structures. The iterative expansion strategy and combination with super-resolution methods like SIM, STED, and STORM offer enhanced resolution without the need for ultra-high-resolution microscopy equipment.

title: Visualization of Single Escherichia coli Cells in the State of SOS Response using Expansion Microscopy
authors: N. A. Rumyantseva, D. M. Golofeeva, I. E. Vishnyakov, A. D. Vedyaykin
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the general principle of expansion microscopy using a bacterial cell model. Fig 2 shows the isotropic expansion of the polyelectrolyte gel in water. Fig 3 describes the chamber setup for bacterial cell attachment to a coverslip. Fig 4 details the chamber used for gel polymerization. Fig 5 outlines the algorithm for embedding bacterial cells in a gel. Fig 6 demonstrates the distribution of FtsZ in E. coli cells during normal division and after UV-induced SOS response. Fig 7 visualizes the uneven distribution of DNA in E. coli cells under normal and SOS response conditions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of the FtsZ protein and DNA distribution in E. coli cells during the SOS response, revealing that FtsZ polymers are not completely disassembled and DNA distribution becomes more uniform. This approach can be applied to study other cells, including eukaryotic cultures.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to visualize single bacterial cells, specifically E. coli, during the SOS response. Unlike previous methods, this approach does not require complex super-resolution microscopy equipment, offering a simpler and cost-effective alternative. The use of Acryloyl-X for anchoring and the visualization of FtsZ protein distribution provides new insights into bacterial cell division under stress conditions, which were previously observed using more complex techniques like single-molecule localization microscopy.

title: Quantitative Analysis of Mitochondrial Shape and Ultrastructure Based on Expansion Microscopy
authors: Alexander Sauer
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the machine learning pipeline for segmenting mitochondria in ExM images, highlighting its scalability. Fig 2: Demonstrates the use of pan-staining combined with additional dyes to reduce human annotation in model training. Fig 3: Presents a novel algorithm leveraging inter-annotator disagreement to enhance semi-supervised segmentation models. Fig 4: Applies the segmentation pipeline to analyze over 60,000 mitochondria, assessing shape and ultrastructure in HeLa cells and mouse kidney tissue.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the development of a machine learning pipeline that automatically segments mitochondria and their ultrastructure in pan-stained ExM images, facilitating scalable quantitative analysis. This approach allows for the combination of pan-staining with additional dyes and immunolabeling, reducing the need for extensive human annotation in training segmentation models.
novelty: This work introduces a machine learning pipeline for ExM images, which is the first to automatically segment mitochondria and their ultrastructure. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach integrates pan-staining with additional dyes and immunolabeling, enhancing the segmentation model's training efficiency. The novel algorithm for handling inter-annotator disagreement further improves semi-supervised segmentation models, setting this study apart from traditional ExM and super-resolution methods.

title: Scalable and Isotropic Expansion of Tissues with Simply Tunable Expansion Ratio
authors: Han-Eol Park, Dongkil Choi, Ji Su Park, Changgon Sim, Sohyun Park, Sunah Kang, Hyunsoo Yim, Myungsun Lee, Jaeyoun Kim, Jinyoung Pac, Kunsoo Rhee, Junho Lee, Yunjong Lee, Yan Lee, Sung-Yon Kim
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the ZOOM process, showing tunable expansion by hydrogel conversion. Fig 2: Illustrates isotropic expansion and preservation of biomolecules, highlighting multi-round expansion capability. Fig 3: Applies ZOOM to cultured cells, resolving subcellular structures like microtubules and mitochondria. Fig 4: Extends ZOOM to mouse brain tissues, enabling visualization of synaptic proteins and rapid volumetric imaging. Fig 5: Showcases ZOOM's applicability to diverse samples, including C. elegans, bacteria, and human brain tissues.
application_goal: The protocol enabled flexible and scalable expansion of biological samples, allowing for nanoscale imaging with conventional microscopes. It supports multi-round expansion for imaging at various zoom factors, preserving biomolecular integrity for post-processing labeling.
novelty: ZOOM introduces a hydrogel conversion-based method for tunable expansion ratios, addressing limitations of fixed expansion in existing methods. It achieves up to eightfold expansion in a single process, surpassing the scalability of previous techniques. The method's simplicity and adaptability to diverse samples, including those with resistant features, mark significant advancements in tissue expansion microscopy.
source_file: Scalable and Isotropic Expansion of Tissues with Simply Tunable Expansion Ratio.pdf

title: Simultaneous expansion microscopy imaging of proteins and mRNAs via dual-ExM
authors: In Cho, Jae-Byum Chang
resolution: beyond the diffraction limit of light
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated mRNA retention after immunostaining, showing over 98% retention of Polr2a mRNA puncta. Fig 2: Showed the necessity of post-fixation in the IF-FISH process to prevent loss of IF signals. Fig 3: Tested different anchoring procedures, all showing over 95% mRNA retention. Fig 4: Described the dual-ExM workflow for simultaneous imaging of proteins and mRNAs. Fig 5: Demonstrated dual-ExM imaging in NIH-3T3 cells, showing improved resolution and separation of closely positioned mRNA puncta. Fig 6: Applied dual-ExM to mouse brain slices, achieving 3D visualization of GFAP protein and Gfap mRNA.
application_goal: The protocol enabled simultaneous super-resolution imaging of both proteins and mRNAs in the same specimen, providing insights into translational regulation and molecular interactions in complex biological systems.
novelty: This study introduces dual-ExM, a technique that allows simultaneous imaging of proteins and mRNAs with resolution beyond the diffraction limit. Unlike previous methods limited to cultured cells or thin slices, dual-ExM is applicable to thick tissue slices and does not require special chemicals, using commercially available reagents. The method improves upon existing ExM techniques by enabling the visualization of both proteins and mRNAs, which is crucial for studying translational regulation and mRNA localization. The use of pre-gel labeling ensures high signal retention, making it a versatile tool for various biological applications.
source_file: Simultaneous expansion microscopy imaging of proteins and mRNAs via dual-ExM.pdf

title: Expansion and Light-Sheet Microscopy for Nanoscale 3D Imaging
authors: Luca Pesce, Pietro Ricci, Giancarlo Sportelli, Nicola Belcari, Giuseppe Sancataldo
summary: Fig 1: Overview of ExM protocols and expansion factors, highlighting the resolution improvement using NPCs. Fig 2: LSFM optical setups and mounting strategies, emphasizing the advantages of inverted LSFM for expanded samples. Fig 3: Demonstration of ExLSFM's capability to image diverse biological samples, showcasing its potential for comprehensive visualization. Fig 4: Comparison of ExLSFM with other super-resolution methods, illustrating its superior resolution and compatibility with various expansion factors.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the integration of ExM with LSFM, termed ExLSFM, allowing for high-resolution, 3D imaging of expanded biological specimens. This approach facilitates the study of intricate cellular structures and protein interactions within their native context, overcoming traditional resolution limits.
novelty: This work presents ExLSFM, a novel integration of ExM and LSFM, offering a powerful super-resolution approach that surpasses traditional diffraction limits. Unlike previous ExM variants, ExLSFM provides rapid, gentle acquisition compatible with diverse sample types and expansion factors, without requiring specific buffers or fluorophores. This advancement enables comprehensive visualization of specimens, enhancing the study of complex biological systems.

title: Orthogonal DNA Self-Assembly-Based Expansion Microscopy Platform for Amplified, Multiplexed Biomarker Imaging
authors: Xiaochen Tang, Wenxing Li, Tianshu Chen, Runchi Zhang, Yilin Yan, Chenbin Liu, Hongquan Gou, Fanping Zhang, Qiuhui Pan, Dongsheng Mao, Xiaoli Zhu
summary: Figure 1 illustrates the o-DAExM platform for in situ amplification analysis of biomarkers, enhancing signal output and resolution. Figure 2 optimizes ExM by varying crosslinker concentration, achieving a balance between expansion capacity and fluorescence retention. Figure 3 compares IF-based ExM and o-DAExM, highlighting the latter's superior signal intensity and structural clarity. Figure 4 demonstrates o-DAExM's enhanced imaging resolution and SNR compared to traditional methods. Figure 5 visualizes exosome structures with o-DAExM, revealing heterogeneity and structural details. Figure 6 showcases multiplexed protein target analysis using o-DAExM, demonstrating its capability for high-throughput imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution and high-sensitivity imaging of cellular structures and exosomes, overcoming limitations of traditional methods by enhancing signal amplification and multiplexing capabilities.
novelty: This work introduces o-DAExM, which combines DNA self-assembly with ExM to achieve superior signal amplification and multiplexing. Compared to prior ExM variants, o-DAExM offers enhanced resolution and SNR without requiring complex equipment. The use of DNA self-assembly for signal amplification is a novel approach that addresses fluorescence loss and low SNR, providing a versatile tool for high-throughput imaging of biological samples.
source_file: Small Methods - 2024 - Tang - Orthogonal DNA Self‐Assembly‐Based Expansion Microscopy Platform for Amplified  Multiplexed.pdf

title: Super-Resolution Imaging in Collagen-Abundant Thick Tissues
authors: Ya-Han Chuang, Yueh-Feng Wu, Ya-Hui Lin, Yin-Hsu Chen, Yu-Xian Zhou, Shao-Chun Hsu, Hsin-Mei Lee, Ann-Shyn Chiang, Yunching Chen, Shiang-Jiuun Chen, Sung-Jan Lin, Li-An Chu
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the successful 4.5-fold expansion of collagen-abundant tissues with minimal distortion, enabling super-resolution imaging. Fig 2 highlights the enhanced transparency and detailed visualization of hair follicle structures post-expansion. Fig 3 shows the visualization of collagen fibers using immunostaining, revealing distinct fiber structures. Fig 4 illustrates the preservation of neuronal structures and mitochondria in expanded tissues, with enhanced signal-to-noise ratio. Fig 5 compares tight junction visualization in corneal endothelium using ColExM and STED, showing superior molecular distribution in ColExM images. Fig 6 explores tight junction disruption under calcium deprivation, mapping dynamic interactions between Zo1 and F-actin.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of nanoscale structures in collagen-rich tissues, overcoming challenges associated with high collagen content. It facilitated detailed mapping of neuronal and tight junction structures, providing insights into tissue architecture and molecular interactions.
novelty: ColExM introduces a novel approach to expanding collagen-abundant tissues, achieving a 4.5-fold expansion with minimal distortion. This method surpasses previous ExM variants by enabling super-resolution imaging without specialized equipment. The use of higher temperatures for enzymatic digestion and the compatibility with immunostaining are significant advancements, allowing detailed visualization of collagen fibers and neuronal structures. Compared to STED and STORM, ColExM offers improved signal-to-noise ratio and molecular distribution, making it a valuable tool for studying complex tissue structures.
source_file: Small Structures - 2024 - Chuang - Super‐Resolution Imaging in Collagen‐Abundant Thick Tissues.pdf

title: Super-resolution Imaging of Clickable Lipids with Lipid Expansion Microscopy (LExM)
authors: Brittany M. White-Mathieu, Jeremy M. Baskin
summary: Fig 1: LExM protocol overview, highlighting the use of permeable reagents for lipid anchoring. Fig 2: Demonstrates ProCho labeling and resolution gain post-LExM, showing clear nuclear membrane delineation. Fig 3: Illustrates the preparation of polymerization masks and gel handling. Fig 4: Shows IMPACT labeling with hexynol, emphasizing nuclear envelope resolution. Fig 5: Displays alkyne-cholesterol labeling, highlighting membrane distribution in expanded samples.
application_goal: The protocol enables super-resolution imaging of cellular membranes using standard confocal microscopes by expanding the sample to achieve a resolution of ~50 nm, without the need for permeabilization that compromises membrane integrity.
novelty: LExM introduces a method for imaging lipids in membranes without permeabilization, overcoming a significant limitation of traditional ExM. Unlike previous methods that required permeabilization, LExM uses a trifunctional fluorophore for anchoring lipids, allowing for detailed membrane studies with a resolution gain to ~50 nm. This approach is particularly novel in its application to lipid imaging, providing a more accessible alternative to specialized super-resolution techniques.
source_file: Super-resolution Imaging of Clickable Lipids with Lipid Expansion Microscopy (LExM).pdf

title: Superresolution expansion microscopy reveals the three-dimensional organization of the Drosophila synaptonemal complex
authors: Cori K. Cahoon, Zulin Yu, Yongfu Wang, Fengli Guo, Jay R. Unruh, Brian D. Slaughter, R. Scott Hawley
summary: Fig 1 shows the SC structure and the expansion protocol. Fig 2 demonstrates ExM SIM images of expanded SC, revealing two layers. Fig 3 provides analysis of average x and z profiles of SC proteins, showing two mirrored SC layers. Fig 4 compares relative positions of CONA, Corolla, and N-C(3)G. Fig 5 presents a 3D model of the Drosophila SC, suggesting two layers of SC connecting homologous sister pairs.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of the Drosophila synaptonemal complex in three dimensions, revealing a dual-layered structure that was previously unresolved with conventional microscopy techniques.
novelty: This study combines expansion microscopy with structured illumination microscopy to achieve a resolution of 25 nm, surpassing the limits of traditional superresolution methods. The work reveals a novel dual-layered organization of the synaptonemal complex in Drosophila, providing insights into its 3D structure. This approach offers a significant advancement over previous methods by allowing detailed visualization of protein arrangements within the complex.

title: Superresolution imaging of Drosophila tissues using expansion microscopy
authors: Nan Jiang, Hyeon-Jin Kim, Tyler J. Chozinski, Jorge E. Azpura, Benjamin A. Eaton, Joshua C. Vaughan, Jay Z. Parrish
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates isotropic expansion of Drosophila tissues, showing pre- and postexpansion imaging. Fig 2: Highlights improved visualization of mitochondria and microtubules postexpansion, revealing fine structural details. Fig 3: Shows superresolution imaging of synapses, revealing AZ substructures not visible with conventional microscopy. Fig 4: Analyzes age-related changes in AZ structure, showing increased AZ area and complexity with age. Fig 5: Uses improved axial resolution to study dendrite-epithelial interactions, revealing extensive dendrite ensheathment.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of Drosophila tissues, allowing for detailed analysis of intracellular structures and intercellular interactions that are not possible with conventional microscopy. This includes the visualization of synaptic structures and dendrite-epithelial interactions, providing insights into cellular mechanisms underlying age-dependent changes in neurotransmission.
novelty: This study extends the utility of ExM to Drosophila tissues, demonstrating its compatibility with various tissue types and highlighting its ability to reveal fine structural details. Compared to prior ExM variants, this work introduces a chitinase treatment step to facilitate expansion of chitin-rich tissues, such as the Drosophila cuticle. The study also benchmarks ExM against other superresolution methods like SIM and STED, showing comparable or superior resolution in certain contexts.
source_file: Superresolution imaging of Drosophila tissues using expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Tetra-gel enables superior accuracy in combined super-resolution imaging and expansion microscopy
authors: Hsuan Lee, Chih-Chieh Yu, Edward S. Boyden, Xiaowei Zhuang, Pallav Kosuri
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated that PA gel embedding does not preserve sub-30 nm structure using DNA origami. Fig 2: Showed that tetra-gel embedding preserves 28-nm structural features even after denaturation, enabling combination with STORM. Fig 3: Tetra-gel ExM increased STORM resolution, resolving 11-nm features in rectangular DNA origami.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the combination of tetra-gel expansion microscopy with STORM to achieve higher resolution imaging without losing structural accuracy, allowing for detailed structural investigations at the nanoscale.
novelty: This study introduces tetra-gel as a superior alternative to traditional PA gels for expansion microscopy, offering improved structural preservation and accuracy. Unlike PA gels, which introduce distortions due to chain-growth radical polymerization, tetra-gel uses click chemistry for a more homogeneous network, preserving sub-10 nm features. This advancement allows for more accurate super-resolution imaging when combined with STORM, surpassing previous ExM variants in both resolution and accuracy.
source_file: Tetra-gel enables superior accuracy in combined super-resolution imaging and expansion microscopy.pdf

title: The Expandables: Cracking the Staphylococcal Cell Wall for Expansion Microscopy
authors: Tobias C. Kunz, Marcel Rühling, Adriana Moldovan, Kerstin Paprotka, Vera Kozjak-Pavlovic, Thomas Rudel, Martin Fraunholz
summary: Fig 1: Developed a protocol for 4x expansion of S. aureus using enzymatic treatments, crucial for overcoming the rigid cell wall. Fig 2: Demonstrated isotropic expansion of S. aureus and other pathogens, enhancing resolution to ~60 nm. Fig 3: Visualized intracellular S. aureus interactions with host vesicles, highlighting the pathogen's escape and survival mechanisms. Fig 4: Combined ExM with SIM to achieve ~30 nm resolution, providing detailed insights into host-pathogen interactions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of the Gram-positive pathogen Staphylococcus aureus, both in planktonic form and within host cells, using standard confocal laser scanning microscopy. This approach allows for detailed visualization of host-pathogen interactions, which is crucial for understanding the mechanisms of infection and immune evasion by S. aureus.
novelty: This study presents a novel protocol for the expansion microscopy of Gram-positive bacteria, specifically Staphylococcus aureus, which traditionally posed challenges due to their robust cell walls. By incorporating lysostaphin into the enzymatic treatment, the study achieved isotropic 4x expansion, a significant improvement over previous methods that struggled with Gram-positive species. The combination of ExM with SIM further enhanced resolution, approaching that of other super-resolution techniques like STED and STORM, but with the advantage of using conventional microscopy equipment.
source_file: The Expandables Cracking the Staphylococcal Cell Wall for Expansion Microscopy.pdf

title: ExPOSE: a comprehensive toolkit to perform expansion microscopy in plant protoplast systems
authors: Kevin L. Cox Jr., Sarah A. Pardi, Lily O’Connor, Anastasiya Klebanovych, David Huss, Dmitri A. Nusinow, Blake C. Meyers, Kirk J. Czymmek
summary: Fig 1: Developed ExPOSE protocol for plant protoplasts, enhancing imaging resolution. Fig 2: Demonstrated robust expansion of Arabidopsis and maize protoplasts, achieving a linear expansion factor of 3.24-3.95x. Fig 3: Enhanced visualization of endogenous actin and mitochondrial matrix proteins using ExPOSE with immunofluorescence. Fig 4: Improved detection of CAB1 mRNA foci with ExPOSE and in situ HCR. Fig 5: Preserved biomolecular condensates, specifically phyB photobodies, using ExPOSE. Fig 6: Revealed distinct localization patterns of MS23 and MS32 transcription factors in maize protoplasts, highlighting their interaction.
application_goal: The ExPOSE protocol enabled the robust expansion of plant protoplasts, allowing for enhanced visualization of subcellular components and biomolecules at increased resolution. This method facilitates the study of protein localization, RNA detection, and biomolecular condensates in plant cells, providing a powerful tool for plant biology research.
novelty: ExPOSE represents a significant advancement in plant expansion microscopy by providing a reliable method for expanding plant protoplasts, a system previously underexplored in ExM. Compared to prior ExM variants, ExPOSE offers a straightforward protocol applicable to different plant species, overcoming challenges associated with plant cell walls. The method enhances resolution and is compatible with super-resolution techniques like SIM, enabling detailed visualization of proteins and RNAs. This work introduces a new anchoring strategy using AcX, demonstrating its effectiveness in preserving biomolecular structures such as condensates, which are challenging to study with traditional microscopy.
source_file: The Plant Journal - 2025 - Cox - ExPOSE  a comprehensive toolkit to perform expansion microscopy in plant protoplast.pdf

title: Multiplexing spatially resolved omics with increased resolution: Development of an expansion microscopy platform
authors: Marisa Vanheusden
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the concept of expansion microscopy and its application to visualize subcellular structures with nanometer precision. Fig 2: Evaluates isotropic expansion and the influence of sample composition on expansion factor. Fig 3: Introduces improved labeling strategies for better fluorescent signal retention. Fig 4: Implements a protein multiplexing readout-scheme in expansion microscopy, referred to as immuno-SABER. Fig 5: Explores resolution achieved when imaging expanded samples on super-resolution microscopy setups.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the study of spatially resolved omics in larger 3D samples by ensuring isotropic expansion and improving labeling strategies for better fluorescent signal retention. This allows for the simultaneous crosslinking of different biomolecules, facilitating a detailed map of cellular identities in intact tissue.
novelty: This work advances expansion microscopy by optimizing the workflow for isotropic expansion and improved labeling strategies, enabling multiplexed protein detection. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach enhances the retention of fluorescent signals and allows for the integration of super-resolution microscopy techniques like STED, achieving nanometer precision. The study contributes to the field by addressing challenges in sample handling and expanding the potential for multi-modal fluorescent detection platforms.

title: Three-Dimensional and Chemical Mapping of Intracellular Signaling Nanodomains in Health and Disease with Enhanced Expansion Microscopy
authors: Thomas M. D. Sheard, Miriam E. Hurley, John Colyer, Ed White, Ruth Norman, Eleftheria Pervolaraki, Kaarjel K. Narayanasamy, Yufeng Hou, Hannah M. Kirton, Zhaokang Yang, Liam Hunter, Jung-uk Shim, Alexander H. Clowsley, Andrew J. Smith, David Baddeley, Christian Soeller, Michael A. Colman, Izzy Jayasinghe
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated the resolution of 10× EExM by comparing it with other microscopy techniques using α-actinin and microtubules in cardiomyocytes. Fig 2: Showed the ability of 10× EExM to resolve RyR nanodomains in cardiomyocytes, revealing punctate labeling densities. Fig 3: Compared RyR organization in control and MCT-RV cells, highlighting smaller and less organized clusters in MCT-RV. Fig 4: Mapped phosphorylation of RyRs, showing differences in phosphorylation patterns between control and MCT-RV cells. Fig 5: Simulated Ca2+ dynamics based on RyR positions and phosphorylation states, illustrating differences in Ca2+ release between control and MCT-RV nanodomains.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of individual RyRs and their phosphorylation states within complex 3D nanodomains in cardiomyocytes, providing insights into the molecular-scale rearrangements and biochemical modifications that occur in health and disease.
novelty: This study presents an enhanced expansion microscopy (EExM) approach that achieves a resolution of ∼15 nm, allowing for the detailed mapping of RyR nanodomains in the interiors of cardiomyocytes. Compared to previous ExM variants and super-resolution methods like dSTORM and DNA-PAINT, 10× EExM offers superior 3D resolution and the ability to map biochemical states, such as phosphorylation, at the single-molecule level. This advancement provides new opportunities for studying the structural and functional dynamics of intracellular signaling nanodomains in health and disease.
source_file: Three-Dimensional and Chemical Mapping of Intracellular Signaling Nanodomains in Health and Disease with Enhanced Expansion Microscopy.pdf

title: TissUExM enables quantitative ultrastructural analysis in whole vertebrate embryos by expansion microscopy
authors: Emmanuelle Steib, Rob Tetley, Romain F. Laine, Dominic P. Norris, Yanlan Mao, Julien Vermot
summary: Fig 1: TissUExM expands whole embryos for protein localization and ultrastructural analysis. Fig 2: Reveals ciliary architecture diversity in zebrafish embryos. Fig 3: Demonstrates TissUExM's versatility in Drosophila and mouse models, preserving organelle structures. The method allows detailed imaging of endogenous proteins in situ, providing insights into tissue-specific ultrastructural features.
application_goal: The protocol enables quantitative imaging of endogenous molecules in whole embryos, preserving the three-dimensional environment. It allows for accurate ultrastructural studies in heterogeneous tissues, facilitating the study of developmental processes and congenital diseases.
novelty: TissUExM offers a significant advancement over previous ExM methods by enabling the expansion of mechanically heterogeneous tissues like whole embryos. Unlike traditional ExM, which often requires thin sections, TissUExM maintains the integrity of large samples, allowing for detailed ultrastructural analysis. The method's ability to preserve endogenous protein localization without the need for fluorescent reporter lines is a notable improvement, providing a more accurate representation of native biological structures.
source_file: TissUExM enables quantitative ultrastructural analysis in whole vertebrate embryos by expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Tracking down the molecular architecture of the synaptonemal complex by expansion microscopy
authors: Fabian U. Zwettler, Marie-Christin Spindler, Sebastian Reinhard, Teresa Klein, Andreas Kurz, Ricardo Benavente, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1: The study visualizes the synaptonemal complex (SC) structure using MAP-SIM, revealing its ladder-like organization. Fig 2: Comparison of SIM and dSTORM images shows MAP-SIM achieves similar resolution with improved labeling. Fig 3: 3D MAP-SIM imaging of SCs demonstrates isotropic expansion and detailed molecular architecture. Fig 4: Lateral views of SCs reveal complex organization of the central region, challenging previous models. Fig 5: MAP-SIM uncovers the splitting of lateral elements, providing insights into SC assembly and disassembly.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of the synaptonemal complex's molecular architecture, revealing previously hidden structural details and allowing for the study of protein organization within the SC at nanoscale resolution.
novelty: This study demonstrates the use of MAP-SIM to achieve isotropic expansion and high-resolution imaging of the synaptonemal complex, surpassing previous ExM variants by providing improved labeling density and resolution. The work highlights the advantages of post-expansion labeling, which reduces linkage error and enhances epitope accessibility, offering a more detailed view of the SC's molecular organization compared to traditional super-resolution methods.
source_file: Tracking down the molecular architecture of the synaptonemal complex by expansion microscopy.pdf

title: Ultrastructure expansion microscopy in Trypanosoma brucei
authors: Ana Kalichava, Torsten Ochsenreiter
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the U-ExM process in T. brucei, highlighting cell preparation and gelation. Fig 2 demonstrates isotropic expansion and resolution improvement, showing expanded cytoskeleton and kDNA. Fig 3 focuses on kDNA visualization during cell cycle stages, revealing structural details. Fig 4 examines basal body structures, using antibodies to localize centrin and SAS6. Fig 5 explores organelle visualization, showing mitochondrial and ER protein distribution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of ultrastructures in Trypanosoma brucei with enhanced resolution, allowing detailed examination of cellular components such as the cytoskeleton, kDNA, and organelles. This facilitates precise localization of proteins and DNA, aiding in the study of cellular architecture and function.
novelty: This study advances the application of U-ExM in Trypanosoma brucei, achieving a higher expansion factor of 4.2-4.6x compared to previous methods. The work demonstrates the ability to visualize detailed structures within the kDNA and cytoskeleton, surpassing traditional microscopy techniques. The use of U-ExM in this protozoan model system provides new insights into cellular organization and offers a powerful tool for studying complex biomolecular structures.

title: Ultrastructure expansion microscopy reveals the cellular architecture of budding and fission yeast
authors: Kerstin Hinterndorfer, Marine H. Laporte, Felix Mikus, Lucas Tafur, Clélia Bourgoint, Manoel Prouteau, Gautam Dey, Robbie Loewith, Paul Guichard, Virginie Hamel
summary: Fig 1: Developed a U-ExM protocol for yeast, optimizing cell wall digestion and fixation. Fig 2: Visualized SPB organization, resolving Tub4 signals at inner and outer plaques. Fig 3: Resolved Sfi1p–Cdc31p complex at SPB, distinguishing half and full bridge structures. Fig 4: Quantified NPCs in S. pombe throughout cell cycle, matching SIM results. Fig 5: Compared cryo-fixation and chemical fixation, showing improved microtubule preservation with cryo-fixation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of the microtubule cytoskeleton and nuclear pore complexes in yeast at nanoscale resolution, facilitating studies of cellular architecture and organelle organization.
novelty: This study extends U-ExM to yeast, overcoming challenges posed by the robust cell wall. The method preserves cellular architecture and allows post-expansion labeling, reducing linkage errors. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach maintains proteome integrity and achieves resolution comparable to SIM, without requiring specialized super-resolution equipment.
source_file: Ultrastructure expansion microscopy reveals the cellular architecture of budding and fission yeast.pdf

title: Using Expansion Microscopy to Visualize and Characterize the Morphology of Mitochondrial Cristae
authors: Tobias C. Kunz, Ralph Götz, Shiqiang Gao, Markus Sauer, Vera Kozjak-Pavlovic
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated the use of MtCK-GFP as a cristae marker in HeLa229 cells, showing comparable resolution to SIM. Fig 2: Used ExM to differentiate between cristae and matrix proteins, showing Mic60/Mitoﬁlin and TFAM localization. Fig 3: SIM-ExM revealed PRX3 localization between cristae and Mic60 near cristae junctions. Fig 4: 3-color ExM showed colocalization of Mic60/Mitoﬁlin and TFAM with cristae. Fig 5: Visualized cristae morphology changes after CCCP treatment and Sam50 knockdown.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of mitochondrial cristae morphology and protein localization using conventional confocal microscopy, without the need for specialized super-resolution setups.
novelty: This study presents the first use of MtCK-GFP as a cristae marker in combination with ExM, allowing for detailed visualization of mitochondrial structures at resolutions comparable to super-resolution methods like dSTORM and STED. The approach simplifies the study of cristae morphology and protein localization, making it accessible to standard cell biology labs.
source_file: Using Expansion Microscopy to Visualize and Characterize the Morphology of Mitochondrial Cristae.pdf

title: Visualizing cellular and tissue ultrastructure using Ten-fold Robust Expansion Microscopy (TREx)
authors: Hugo GJ Damstra, Boaz Mohar, Mark Eddison, Anna Akhmanova, Lukas C Kapitein, Paul W Tillberg
summary: Fig 1: Explores the expansion recipe space, identifying optimal crosslinker concentrations for TREx. Fig 2: Demonstrates TREx in mouse brain tissue, showing detailed protein and membrane structures. Fig 3: Validates isotropy of TREx using nuclear pore complexes and microtubules. Fig 4: Shows TREx application in cultured cells, visualizing membranes and organelles. Fig 5: Combines TREx with antibody and NHS ester staining for subcellular context.
application_goal: The TREx protocol enables high-resolution imaging of cellular and tissue ultrastructure by expanding samples tenfold in a single step, allowing detailed visualization of proteins and membranes in both thick tissue sections and cultured cells.
novelty: TREx offers a significant improvement over previous ExM methods by achieving a tenfold expansion in a single step without compromising gel integrity. Unlike iterative ExM, TREx is simpler and more accessible, requiring no specialized equipment. The method's robustness and compatibility with various sample types and stains make it a versatile tool for high-resolution imaging.
source_file: Visualizing cellular and tissue ultrastructure using Ten-fold Robust Expansion Microscopy (TREx).pdf

title: Visualizing the native cellular organization by coupling cryofixation with expansion microscopy (Cryo-ExM)
authors: Marine H. Laporte, Nikolai Klena, Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard
summary: Fig 1: Developed Cryo-ExM by combining cryofixation with expansion microscopy to preserve cellular ultrastructure. Fig 2: Demonstrated Cryo-ExM captures ER-microtubule interactions and mitochondrial organization. Fig 3: Showed Cryo-ExM preserves cytoskeletal elements like actin and microtubules in neurons and U2OS cells. Fig 4: Highlighted improved epitope accessibility with Cryo-ExM compared to chemical fixation. Fig 5: Demonstrated versatility of Cryo-ExM in preserving various cellular structures and phase-separated organelles.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of subcellular compartments without chemical fixation artifacts, preserving native cellular organization and improving epitope accessibility for more accurate protein localization.
novelty: Cryo-ExM introduces a novel combination of cryofixation with expansion microscopy, offering superior preservation of cellular ultrastructure compared to traditional chemical fixation methods. This approach enhances epitope accessibility and maintains the native state of cellular structures, providing a significant advancement over previous ExM variants and super-resolution methods. The method's compatibility with existing cryo-substitution protocols and potential application to tissue samples further underscores its innovative contribution to the field.
source_file: Visualizing the native cellular organization by coupling cryofixation with expansion microscopy (Cryo-ExM).pdf

title: Volumetric, Nanoscale Optical Imaging of Mouse and Human Kidney via Expansion Microscopy
authors: Tyler J. Chozinski, Chenyi Mao, Aaron R. Halpern, Jeffrey W. Pippin, Stuart J. Shankland, Charles E. Alpers, Behzad Najafian, Joshua C. Vaughan
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the ExM process and its validation in mouse kidney, showing successful expansion and resolution of podocyte foot processes. Fig 2: Illustrates confocal ExM images of mouse kidney labeled with antibodies, resolving glomerular structures. Fig 3: Quantifies GBM thickness and foot process width, providing metrics relevant to clinical use. Fig 4: Shows confocal ExM images of expanded human kidney tissue, validating the method for human samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of fine structural details of kidney tissues, such as podocyte foot processes and the glomerular basement membrane, which were previously difficult to resolve with conventional light microscopy.
novelty: This study presents an optimized ExM protocol for mouse and human kidney tissues, achieving 70-75 nm resolution using standard confocal microscopy. The work introduces new homogenization strategies for enzymatic digestion of the extracellular matrix, enabling minimal distortion upon expansion. Compared to previous ExM studies, this protocol allows for the imaging of intrinsic fluorescent proteins and provides a detailed quantitative analysis of expansion-induced distortions.
source_file: Volumetric, Nanoscale Optical Imaging of Mouse and Human Kidney via Expansion Microscopy.pdf

title: Whole-brain imaging with ExLLSM
authors: Gao, R. et al.
summary: Fig 1: ExM combined with LLSM for brain imaging, enabling detailed structural visualization. Fig 2: Imaging of mouse cortical column, demonstrating high-resolution capabilities. Fig 3: Whole Drosophila brain imaged, showcasing volumetric imaging potential. Fig 4: Data handling tools developed for large image volumes, facilitating analysis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of entire brains, allowing detailed structural studies of complex neural architectures.
novelty: This study introduces ExLLSM, combining expansion microscopy with lattice light-sheet microscopy, achieving super-resolution imaging of entire brains. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach allows for fast, high-resolution volumetric imaging with low light doses, expanding the potential for detailed brain studies.

title: X10 expansion microscopy enables 25-nm resolution on conventional microscopes
authors: Sven Truckenbrodt, Manuel Maidorn, Dagmar Crzan, Hanna Wildhagen, Selda Kabatas, Silvio O Rizzoli
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the X10 gel polymerization reactions, highlighting critical steps. Fig 2: Demonstrates X10's ability to achieve super-resolution on conventional microscopes, showing tubulin network in COS7 cells. Fig 3: Validates X10's resolution of ~25 nm using peroxisomes in neurons, comparing with STED and STORM. Fig 4: Shows multi-color imaging of synaptic structures in cultured neurons, resolving synaptic vesicle clusters and active zones. Fig 5: Applies X10 to brain slices, achieving similar resolution enhancement, demonstrating compatibility with tissue samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of biological samples using conventional epifluorescence microscopes, achieving resolutions comparable to advanced STED and STORM setups without requiring specialized equipment or complex analysis.
novelty: X10 microscopy introduces a single-step expansion protocol achieving 10x expansion, providing 25-30 nm resolution on conventional microscopes. This is a significant improvement over traditional 4x expansion methods, which achieve ~70 nm resolution. Unlike iterative expansion microscopy (iExM), which requires multiple steps and custom antibodies, X10 is simpler, faster, and compatible with standard antibodies, making it accessible for general biology labs.
source_file: X10 expansion microscopy enables 25‐nm resolution on conventional microscopes.pdf

title: A Universal Labeling Strategy for Nucleic Acids in Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Marisa Vanheusden, Volker Leen, Taoufik Rohand, Katy Vandereyken, Thierry Voet, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1: Introduces the TRITON approach for labeling nucleic acids in ExM, enhancing RNA detection. Fig 2: Describes the synthesis and optimization of chemical probes for nucleic acids, focusing on labeling efficiency. Fig 3: Demonstrates immunostaining using TRITON-based readout probes in ×4 and ×10 ExM, achieving high resolution. Fig 4: Validates mRNA detection via ExM combined with HCR v3.0, showing high specificity and sensitivity.
application_goal: The protocol enables the rapid functionalization of DNA oligonucleotides for use in ExM, allowing for high-resolution imaging of nucleic acids and facilitating multicolor analysis in expanded samples.
novelty: This study introduces a universal labeling strategy using TRITON linkers for nucleic acids in ExM, achieving high resolution and compatibility with existing RNA FISH techniques. Compared to prior ExM variants, this approach offers a single-step labeling process and improved anchoring efficiency, enabling the detection of RNA with high specificity and sensitivity. The use of TRITON linkers represents a significant advancement in the field, providing a versatile tool for nucleic acid imaging in expanded samples.

title: An Image-Based High-Throughput and High-Content Drug Screening Method Based on Microarray and Expansion Microscopy
authors: Junfang Xie, Daobo Han, Shuai Xu, Haitong Zhang, Yonghe Li, Mingshan Zhang, Zhichao Deng, Jianguo Tian, Qing Ye
summary: Fig 1: Developed a high-throughput, high-content drug screening method using SMAP and proExM, improving efficiency. Fig 2: Demonstrated SMAP preparation and cell culture, showing high cell viability and no cross-contamination. Fig 3: Combined SMAP with proExM, achieving 68 nm resolution and high-throughput imaging. Fig 4: Analyzed microtubule morphology changes under docetaxel treatment, revealing drug effects. Fig 5: Evaluated microtubule density changes with β-elemene, highlighting ExM's resolution advantage. Fig 6: Assessed mitochondrial morphology in untreated cells, establishing a baseline for drug effects. Fig 7: Quantified mitochondrial changes under CCCP, demonstrating ExM's utility in pharmacodynamics.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-throughput and high-content drug screening by combining a superhydrophobic microwell array plate (SMAP) with protein-retention expansion microscopy (proExM). This method allows for efficient observation of morphological changes in cells and organelles, providing a powerful tool for evaluating pharmacodynamics and drug effects on cellular ultrastructure.
novelty: This study presents a novel combination of SMAP and proExM, offering a high-throughput and high-content drug screening method. Unlike traditional methods, this approach does not rely on silicon molds, allowing flexible microwell geometry. The integration of proExM enables super-resolution imaging without specialized equipment, achieving 68 nm resolution. This method significantly reduces time and reagent consumption compared to existing techniques, providing a practical solution for early drug screening and pharmacodynamics evaluation.

title: Aptamer-Based Cell Nucleus Imaging via Expansion Microscopy
authors: Yue Sun, Zhicheng Zhang, Tao Bing, Jing Liu, Weiwei Li, Xiangjun Liu, Nan Zhang, Yang Shu, Jianhua Wang, Dihua Shangguan
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the expansion of polyacrylamide gel and the clear imaging of expanded nuclei using confocal microscopy. Fig 2: Shows colocalization experiments with nuclear dyes and histone antibody, highlighting the specificity of Ac-Ch4−1-FAM for nuclear imaging. Fig 3: Illustrates the imaging of chromatin morphology at different mitotic stages, revealing structural details such as interchromatin compartments and nucleoli rims.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of cell nuclei by using an aptamer-based expansion microscopy strategy. This approach simplifies the labeling process by using a dual-labeled aptamer for molecular recognition, fluorescence reporting, and gel anchoring, allowing for clear visualization of chromatin morphology at different mitotic stages.
novelty: This study introduces an aptamer-based expansion microscopy technique that simplifies the traditional ExM process by eliminating the need for complex immunolabeling and chemical handle labeling. The use of a dual-labeled aptamer for direct gel anchoring and fluorescence reporting offers a streamlined approach to imaging nuclear structures with high resolution. Compared to previous ExM variants, this method provides a simpler and potentially more versatile strategy for super-resolution imaging of cellular components.

title: Mechanically resolved imaging of bacteria using expansion microscopy
authors: Youngbin Lim, Anthony L. Shiver, Margarita Khariton, Keara M. Lane, Katharine M. Ng, Samuel R. Bray, Jian Qin, Kerwyn Casey Huang, Bo Wang
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates differential expansion of bacterial species using μExM, highlighting the method's ability to distinguish species based on cell wall properties. Fig 2 extends these findings to human gut commensals, showing μExM's utility in quantifying species composition in mixed communities. Fig 3 reveals μExM's sensitivity to antibiotic-induced cell wall damage, providing a novel assay for detecting submicrometer pores. Fig 4 applies μExM to in vivo imaging of planarian gut microbiota, resolving species without fluorescent tags. Fig 5 uncovers phenotypic heterogeneity in Salmonella during macrophage infection, suggesting variability in cell wall integrity.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the resolution of bacterial species within complex communities and in vivo environments, providing a new contrast mechanism based on cell wall mechanics. This allows for the study of microbial interactions and phenotypic heterogeneity in ways not possible with traditional fluorescence microscopy.
novelty: This study introduces μExM, a variant of expansion microscopy tailored for bacteria, which leverages differential expansion based on cell wall properties to provide a new imaging contrast. Unlike previous ExM methods focused on uniform expansion, μExM exploits species-specific expansion differences, offering a sensitive tool for distinguishing bacterial species and detecting cell wall damage. This approach is particularly advantageous for genetically intractable species and complements existing super-resolution techniques by providing additional mechanical contrast.

title: Bio-orthogonal Glycan Imaging of Cultured Cells and Whole Animal C. elegans with Expansion Microscopy
authors: Joe Chin-Hun Kuo, Marshall J. Colville, Michelle R. Sorkin, Jacky Lok Ka Kuo, Ling Ting Huang, Dana N. Thornlow, Gwendolyn M. Beacham, Gunther Hollopeter, Matthew P. DeLisa, Christopher A. Alabi, Matthew J. Paszek
summary: Fig 1: Developed multifunctional linkers for imaging metabolically tagged molecules with ExM, enabling visualization of glycans. Fig 2: Validated linkers on mammalian cells, demonstrating specific and stable integration into the gel matrix. Fig 3: Combined ExM with proExM to visualize glycans and proteins on MCF10A cells, showing compatibility with existing protocols. Fig 4: Applied linkers to C. elegans, achieving nanoscale resolution of anatomical features. Fig 5: Mapped O-glycosylation in C. elegans, revealing glycan-enriched structures not previously resolved by optical microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of glycans at nanoscale resolution in both cultured cells and whole organisms, providing a new method for mapping glycan distribution and structure in biological samples. This approach allows for detailed study of glycan-enriched structures and their roles in cellular and organismal physiology.
novelty: This work introduces a new class of multifunctional linkers for ExM, allowing for the specific and stable visualization of metabolically labeled glycans. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach provides enhanced resolution and the ability to map glycans in whole organisms like C. elegans. The use of bio-orthogonal chemistry and the development of a modular synthesis platform for linkers represent significant advancements in the field, enabling broader applications in glycan imaging.

title: Expansion tomography for large volume tissue imaging with nanoscale resolution
authors: RUIXI CHEN, XIAOFENG CHENG, YONGSHENG ZHANG, XIONG YANG, YU WANG, XIULI LIU, SHAOQUN ZENG
summary: Fig 1 introduces the ExT strategy, highlighting its ability to achieve nanoscale resolution in large tissue volumes. Fig 2 details the development of the ExT gel, emphasizing its high mechanical strength and expansion factor. Fig 3 demonstrates the application of ExT in imaging mouse brain and U-2 OS cells, showcasing improved resolution and fluorescence retention. Fig 4 presents 3D super-resolution imaging of mouse brain tissue using the HLTP system, illustrating detailed neuronal structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the imaging of large tissue volumes with nanoscale resolution, overcoming the limitations of working distance in conventional microscopy. This allows for detailed visualization of neuronal circuits and other complex biological structures in their entirety.
novelty: This work introduces ExT, a novel expansion tomography strategy that combines high mechanical strength hydrogels with a high-throughput light-sheet tomography system. Compared to previous ExM variants, ExT offers improved mechanical properties for continuous sectioning and imaging of large samples. The integration with HLTP allows for rapid acquisition of super-resolution data, significantly reducing imaging time compared to traditional methods.

title: Plasmonic nanoparticle-based expansion microscopy with surface-enhanced Raman and dark-field spectroscopic imaging
authors: CAMILLE G. ARTUR, TASHA WOMACK, FUSHENG ZHAO, JASON L. ERIKSEN, DAVID MAYERICH, WEI-CHUAN SHIH
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the use of plasmonic nanoparticles for enhanced imaging contrast and photostability. Fig 2 shows the application of surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) for multimodal imaging. Fig 3 highlights the dark-field spectroscopic imaging capabilities, emphasizing the method's versatility.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of plasmonic nanoparticles to enhance imaging contrast and photostability in expansion microscopy, allowing for multimodal imaging with bright-field, dark-field, and SERS techniques.
novelty: This study introduces the use of plasmonic nanoparticles in expansion microscopy to address issues of photostability and signal intensity reduction. Unlike traditional fluorescence-based ExM, this approach leverages surface-enhanced Raman scattering for improved contrast and brightness, offering a new avenue for multimodal imaging.

title: Expansion enhanced nanoscopy
authors: Rongqin Li, Xuanze Chen, Zixi Lin, Yao Wang, Yujie Sun
summary: Fig 1: ExSTED imaging of microtubules in BS-C-1 cells showed improved resolution with a novel re-labeling strategy. Fig 2: ExSTED resolved the ring-like arrangement of Nup133 in nuclear pore complexes and improved visualization of synaptic structures in mouse brain slices. Fig 3: ExSOFI using Qdots achieved high-resolution imaging of microtubules and clathrin-coated pits, demonstrating multiplexed imaging capabilities.
application_goal: The protocol enabled enhanced spatial resolution in super-resolution imaging techniques by combining expansion microscopy with STED and SOFI, allowing detailed visualization of cellular and tissue structures.
novelty: This work introduces a novel re-labeling strategy post-expansion to enhance fluorescence labeling density, achieving significant resolution improvements in ExSTED and ExSOFI. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach provides a simple and effective method for resolution enhancement without the need for complex optical setups or special probes. The use of Qdots in ExSOFI further enhances imaging capabilities, offering a robust alternative to traditional dyes.

title: Expansion Microscopy of the Enteric Nervous System: A Feasibility Study
authors: Xin Xu, Wenchuan Zhang, Menachem Hanani
sample: mouse colonic ENS tissue, external muscle layers with the myenteric plexus
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the expansion of neuronal somata and fibers in the myenteric plexus, highlighting the increased visibility of neuronal structures. Fig 2: Shows fluorescence imaging of glial cells, emphasizing the enhanced resolution of glial processes post-expansion. The study validates the protocol's ability to preserve tissue architecture while achieving significant expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution structural analysis of the enteric nervous system, allowing for detailed visualization of neuronal and glial structures that were previously unresolvable with conventional microscopy.
novelty: This study represents a novel application of expansion microscopy to the enteric nervous system, a previously unexplored area for ExM. By optimizing the protocol to avoid collagenase, the study simplifies the expansion process while preserving tissue integrity. This work extends the utility of ExM beyond brain tissues to peripheral nervous systems, offering new insights into the structural organization of the ENS.
