title: Nanoscale Imaging of RNA with Expansion Microscopy
authors: Fei Chen, Asmamaw T. Wassie, Allison J. Cote, Anubhav Sinha, Shahar Alon, Shoh Asano, Evan R. Daugharthy, Jae-Byum Chang, Adam Marblestone, George M. Church, Arjun Raj, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Developed LabelX for RNA anchoring to ExM gel, enabling smFISH post-expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrated multiplexed RNA imaging with ExFISH, showing stability across multiple FISH cycles. Fig 3: Applied ExFISH to mouse brain tissue, visualizing mRNA with HCR amplification, achieving single molecule precision in thick specimens.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of RNA structures and localization with nanoscale precision in intact tissues, facilitating the study of RNA's structural roles and its association with cellular compartments.
novelty: This work introduces a novel reagent, LabelX, for covalently anchoring RNA to the ExM gel, enabling nanoscale imaging of RNA with single molecule precision. Compared to previous ExM variants, ExFISH allows for the visualization of RNA structures and localization in thick tissues, such as brain, with high specificity and yield. The combination of ExM with FISH and HCR amplification provides a powerful tool for super-resolution imaging of RNA, surpassing traditional diffraction-limited microscopy methods.

title: PAExM: label-free hyper-resolution photoacoustic expansion microscopy
authors: Hyojin Kim, Jin Woo Baik, Seungwan Jeon, Jin Young Kim, Chulhong Kim
summary: Fig 1: Developed a high-speed reflection-mode UV-PAM system for imaging. Fig 2: Demonstrated label-free PA histological imaging of mouse brain sections before and after expansion, showing improved resolution. Fig 3: Showed volumetric expansion and separation of nuclei in expanded samples. Fig 4: Highlighted optical sectioning capability in expanded samples, visualizing volumetric architecture.
application_goal: The protocol enabled label-free imaging of cell nuclei in expanded mouse brain sections, improving the separation ability of densely distributed nuclei without the need for staining.
novelty: This study introduces PAExM, combining photoacoustic microscopy with tissue expansion to achieve label-free imaging of cell nuclei with enhanced resolution. Unlike traditional UV-PAM, which requires staining, PAExM leverages the intrinsic optical absorption of nucleic acids, offering a simpler and faster imaging protocol. The expansion factor of 1.9x allows for better separation of closely packed nuclei, a significant improvement over previous methods.

title: Photoacoustic expansion microscopy of melanosomes
authors: Tingting Li, Xinrui Gong, Heng Guo, Lei Xi
summary: Fig 1: Configuration of the OR-PAM system and its performance in imaging nanoparticles. Fig 2: Expansion protocol for melanoma cells and a typical PA-ExM image showing melanosome distribution. Fig 3: Comparative imaging of B16-F10 cells with different expansion rates, demonstrating improved resolution with increased expansion. Fig 4: 3D imaging comparison of unexpanded and 64x expanded B16-F10 cells, highlighting enhanced axial resolution and melanosome separation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled super-resolution imaging of melanosomes in melanoma cells by combining expansion microscopy with photoacoustic imaging, allowing for detailed visualization of subcellular structures without the need for ultrahigh numerical aperture objectives.
novelty: This study introduces PA-ExM, which combines the advantages of OR-PAM and ExM to achieve super-resolution imaging of melanosomes. Unlike previous methods that rely on ultrahigh NA objectives or complex nonlinear mechanisms, PA-ExM uses physical expansion to enhance resolution, reducing costs and photobleaching risks. The approach allows for detailed visualization of melanosomes in melanoma cells, demonstrating significant improvements over traditional OR-PAM and other super-resolution techniques.

title: Optimized expansion microscopy reveals species-specific spindle microtubule organization in Xenopus egg extracts
authors: Gabriel Guilloux, Maiko Kitaoka, Karel Mocaer, Claire Heichette, Laurence Duchesne, Rebecca Heald, Thierry Pecot, Romain Gibeaux
summary: Fig 1: Developed a workflow for ExM of Xenopus egg extract spindles, optimizing fixation and gelation. Fig 2: Compared expansion factors and distortions across protocols, selecting U-ExM gel with thermal denaturation for minimal distortion. Fig 3: Demonstrated resolution improvement, enabling individual microtubule bundle segmentation. Fig 4: Evaluated postcentrifugation fixation effects, finding MAD fixation better preserves microtubule integrity. Fig 5: Reduced fixation duration to improve microtubule straightness and spindle length. Fig 6: Developed analysis workflow to compare microtubule bundle organization between X. laevis and X. tropicalis. Fig 7: Analyzed organizational differences, revealing species-specific microtubule bundle distributions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of spindle microtubule organization in Xenopus egg extracts, revealing species-specific differences in spindle architecture. This approach allows for detailed analysis of microtubule bundles and their distribution, providing insights into spindle morphology and function.
novelty: This study presents an optimized ExM protocol for Xenopus egg extracts, achieving a resolution of 77.23 nm. The work highlights the ability to preserve and visualize microtubule bundles in spindles, revealing species-specific architectural differences between X. laevis and X. tropicalis. Compared to previous ExM variants, this protocol offers improved preservation of spindle integrity and compatibility with preexpansion immunofluorescence, enabling detailed analysis of spindle components and their organization.

title: ExCIDS: a combined approach coupling Expansion Microscopy (ExM) and Circular Intensity Differential Scattering (CIDS) for chromatin-DNA imaging
authors: RICCARDO MARONGIU, AYMERIC LE GRATIET, LUCA PESCE, PAOLO BIANCHINI, ALBERTO DIASPRO
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the improved resolution of chromatin-DNA using ExCIDS, highlighting the nuclear membrane and heterochromatin structure. Fig 2: Illustrates the scattering process and SNR decrease post-expansion. Fig 3: Shows pixel distribution histograms, indicating improved correlation between CIDS and fluorescence post-expansion. Fig 4: Compares CIDS and fluorescence images at different digestion times, showing enhanced contrast with increased digestion. Fig 5: Displays normalized 3D histograms, highlighting improved correlation after overnight digestion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of chromatin-DNA organization in situ with enhanced resolution and contrast by combining expansion microscopy with circular intensity differential scattering, allowing for detailed study of nuclear structures without isolating nuclei.
novelty: This study introduces ExCIDS, a novel combination of expansion microscopy and CIDS, providing enhanced resolution and contrast for chromatin-DNA imaging. Unlike previous ExM variants, ExCIDS offers label-free sensitivity to chiral molecular organization, improving the optical resolution and correlation with fluorescence imaging. The approach reduces scattering artifacts and preserves native chromatin organization, offering a significant advancement over traditional super-resolution methods.

title: Optimizing Scanning Bessel Beam Light Sheet Microscopy with Custom-designed Lens Cap for Expansion Microscopy
authors: Chia-Ming Lee, Xuejiao Tian, Min-Ju Tsai, Bi-Chang Chen
combined_with: Scanning Bessel Beam Light Sheet Microscopy
summary: Fig 1A shows the system diagram of Scanning Bessel Beam Light Sheet Microscopy. Fig 1B compares light sheet images of expanded zebrafish liver using flat windows versus a custom lens cap, demonstrating improved signal capture with the lens cap. Fig 1C presents signal profiles indicating higher signal values with the custom lens cap, highlighting its effectiveness in reducing background noise.
application_goal: The protocol enabled faster acquisition of high-quality light sheet images for large ExM samples, facilitating scientific discoveries by improving image quality and reducing sample vibration.
novelty: This study introduces a custom-designed lens cap that converts a standard Olympus NA 0.28 4X dry objective into an immersion objective with a longer working distance, providing a cost-effective alternative to expensive custom detection objectives. The system also incorporates progressive z scanning to minimize sample vibration, enhancing image quality. These innovations offer significant improvements over previous ExM methods, particularly for imaging large samples.

title: From Trypomastigotes to Trypomastigotes: Analyzing the One-Way Intracellular Journey of Trypanosoma cruzi by Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy
authors: Ramiro Tomasina, Fabiana C. González, Andrés Cabrera, Yester Basmadjián, Carlos Robello
summary: Fig 1: Visualized trypomastigotes and intermediate forms in host cells, highlighting morphological changes. Fig 2: Proposed model of amastigogenesis, showing trypomastigote transformation into amastigotes. Fig 3: Identified three distinct dividing forms at 24 hours post-infection, indicating stages of intracellular trypomastigogenesis. Fig 4: Observed diverse life forms at 72 hours post-infection, including epimastigote-like forms. Fig 5: Detailed amastigote cell division, revealing semi-closed nuclear mitosis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of Trypanosoma cruzi's intracellular life cycle stages, providing insights into the morphological transformations from trypomastigote to amastigote and back, crucial for understanding the pathogenesis of Chagas disease.
novelty: This study employs Ultrastructure Expansion Microscopy (UExM) to achieve unprecedented resolution in visualizing the intracellular life cycle of Trypanosoma cruzi. Unlike previous methods, UExM allows for detailed observation of intermediate forms and cellular transformations, providing new insights into the parasite's replication and differentiation processes. The study highlights the presence of non-replicative epimastigote-like forms and proposes a model for amastigogenesis, contributing to a deeper understanding of T. cruzi biology.

title: Plasmon-Enhanced Expansion Microscopy
authors: Priya Rathi, Prashant Gupta, Avishek Debnath, Harsh Baldi, Yixuan Wang, Rohit Gupta, Baranidharan Raman, Srikanth Singamaneni
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the structure and fluorescence enhancement of plasmonic-fluors (PFs), highlighting their brightness compared to conventional dyes. Fig 2 demonstrates the stability and fluorescence retention of PFs post-expansion, showing 85% retention. Fig 3 shows improved spatial resolution and fidelity of p-ExM, with PFs enabling better visualization of neuronal structures. Fig 4 quantifies neuronal morphological features, revealing increased neurite terminal points post-expansion. Fig 5 addresses diffusion limitations of PFs, proposing a cyclic draining and replenishment method to improve labeling efficiency.
application_goal: The protocol enabled improved visualization and quantification of neuronal structures, overcoming fluorescence signal dilution challenges in expansion microscopy. The use of plasmonic-fluors allowed for enhanced resolution and accurate mapping of neural networks, facilitating better understanding of neuronal morphology.
novelty: This study introduces plasmon-enhanced expansion microscopy (p-ExM) using ultrabright plasmonic-fluors, which retain 85% of their fluorescence post-expansion, compared to significant signal loss in conventional fluorophores. The method offers improved spatial resolution and fidelity, enabling detailed analysis of neuronal structures. Unlike previous ExM variants, p-ExM addresses signal dilution challenges, making it a valuable tool for probing low-abundance markers and complex biological systems.

title: Practical method for superresolution imaging of primary cilia and centrioles by expansion microscopy using an amplibody for fluorescence signal amplification
authors: Yohei Katoh, Shuhei Chiba, Kazuhisa Nakayama
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the expansion process and compares nonexpanded and expanded cells, highlighting the improved resolution of ciliary structures. Figure 2 shows the enhanced imaging of cilia and centrioles using SIM and Airyscan, emphasizing the distinct distribution of proteins. Figure 3 introduces amplibodies for signal amplification, validating their effectiveness in enhancing fluorescence signals. Figure 4 explores the localization of centriolar and ciliary proteins using amplibody-proExM, revealing detailed structural insights. Figure 5 applies three-color amplibody-proExM to study IFT88 dynamics during ciliogenesis, providing insights into protein localization changes.
application_goal: The protocol enabled practical subdiffraction imaging of primary cilia and centrioles, allowing for the observation of structures that are indistinguishable using conventional fluorescence microscopy. The use of amplibodies significantly enhanced fluorescence signals, facilitating detailed analysis of protein localization and distribution.
novelty: This study introduces the use of amplibodies for fluorescence signal amplification in expansion microscopy, addressing the challenge of reduced signal intensity due to sample expansion. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach allows for improved imaging of ciliary and centriolar structures with enhanced resolution. The combination of proExM with Airyscan and SIM provides a practical and effective method for high-resolution imaging, surpassing the limitations of conventional superresolution techniques.

title: Nanoscale imaging using differential expansion microscopy
authors: Sebastian P. Pernal, Asiri Liyanaarachchi, Domenico L. Gatti, Brent Formosa, Rishika Pulvender, Eric R. Kuhn, Rafael Ramos, Akshata R. Naik, Kathleen George, Suzan Arslanturk, Douglas J. Taatjes, Bhanu P. Jena
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates optimized fixation protocol for rat liver tissue, achieving up to eightfold expansion. Fig 2: Shows anisotropic expansion in human skeletal muscle cells, highlighting differential expansion of nucleus and myosin fibers. Fig 3: Describes computational analysis of expanded images, confirming anisotropic expansion and providing quantitative morphometric data. Fig 4: Compares new protocol with previous methods, emphasizing improved expansion and retention of cellular integrity.
application_goal: The protocol enabled precise, rapid, and inexpensive diagnosis of disease from pathological specimen slides by achieving significant expansion of biological samples while retaining structural integrity and antigenicity.
novelty: This study introduces differential expansion microscopy (DiExM), which achieves greater expansion factors than previous ExM variants, such as the 10× Microscopy, while retaining immunolabeled antigens. The work highlights the anisotropic nature of expansion across different tissues and organelles, providing a new approach to assess cellular morphology and pathology. The use of machine learning to analyze expanded images further distinguishes this method from prior techniques.

summary: Fig 1: Validated U-ExM in T. cruzi, showing antibody specificity via western blot. Fig 2: Demonstrated localization of α- and β-tubulin in T. cruzi, highlighting subpellicular microtubules and flagellar axoneme. Fig 3: Showed acetylated and tyrosinated α-tubulin localization, emphasizing differences in microtubule stability and formation. Measured expansion factors for nucleus and kinetoplast, confirming homogeneous expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization of cytoskeletal structures in T. cruzi, allowing for the study of tubulin isoforms and isotypes across different life cycle stages. This approach provides a robust method for high-resolution imaging of subcellular structures, enhancing our understanding of T. cruzi biology.
novelty: This study introduces U-ExM for T. cruzi, expanding its application beyond previously studied protozoan parasites. The work highlights the technique's ability to achieve ∼65 nm resolution using conventional confocal microscopy, a significant improvement over standard methods. The use of U-ExM in all life cycle stages of T. cruzi and the detailed protocol for tubulin isoform localization represent advancements in the field, offering new insights into the cytoskeletal architecture of this kinetoplastid parasite.

title: Prospects and limitations of expansion microscopy in chromatin ultrastructure determination
authors: Ivona Kubalová, Markéta Schmidt Černohorská, Martina Huranová, Klaus Weisshart, Andreas Houben, Veit Schubert
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the expansion of isolated barley nuclei using different fixation and denaturation conditions to maintain chromatin ultrastructure. Fig 2: Compares the chromatin structure of unexpanded and expanded nuclei using wide-field, deconvolution, and structured illumination microscopy. Fig 3: Shows the effect of different denaturation methods on chromatin preservation, highlighting the use of NaOH in ethanol. Fig 4: Illustrates the improved chromatin structure preservation without denaturation or digestion. Fig 5: Visualizes centromeric repeats in expanded nuclei using non-denaturating FISH, showing Rabl orientation. Fig 6: Displays the localization of CENH3 in expanded nuclei, indicating preserved centromeric positions but altered chromatin ultrastructure.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of chromatin structures in isolated barley nuclei at a resolution of 25-35 nm, revealing chromatin domains and centromeric repeats that are not visible in unexpanded nuclei. This approach allows for the analysis of chromatin organization and the localization of specific DNA sequences and proteins within expanded nuclei.
novelty: This study applies expansion microscopy to isolated plant nuclei, specifically barley, to achieve a physical expansion factor of 4.2x. The work highlights the challenges of preserving chromatin ultrastructure during expansion, which is not fully addressed by existing ExM protocols. Unlike previous ExM applications on animal tissues, this study focuses on plant chromatin, revealing the limitations of current protocols in maintaining chromatin integrity. The combination with SIM provides higher resolution imaging, but the chromatin substructure is still compromised, indicating the need for further protocol optimization.

title: Nanoscale fluorescence imaging of biological ultrastructure via molecular anchoring and physical expansion
authors: Wei Wang, Yat Ho Chan, SoYoung Kwon, Jamuna Tandukar, Ruixuan Gao
summary: Fig 1: Describes the principle of super-resolution microscopy techniques like STED, SIM, and SMLM, highlighting their ability to achieve sub-diffraction-limit imaging. Fig 2: Outlines the general workflow of expansion microscopy (ExM), emphasizing the steps of anchoring, polymerization, homogenization, and expansion. Fig 3: Demonstrates the application of proExM to visualize microtubules in HeLa cells at ~70 nm resolution. Fig 4: Shows the imaging of the entire Drosophila brain using a modified proExM at sub-100 nm resolution. Fig 5: Illustrates the use of MA-NHS anchoring strategy to visualize synaptic markers in mouse brain slices at sub-100 nm resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of biological ultrastructures at nanoscale resolution by physically expanding the samples, thus overcoming the diffraction limit of conventional light microscopy.
novelty: This work reviews the development and application of expansion microscopy (ExM), a technique that allows for nanoscale imaging by physically expanding biological samples. Unlike traditional super-resolution methods that modify the optics, ExM increases sample size to achieve high resolution. The review highlights various anchoring strategies and ExM variants, such as proExM and MA-NHS-based ExM, which have been applied to diverse biological samples. The ability to retain and visualize a wide range of biomolecules, including proteins and nucleic acids, sets ExM apart from other methods.

title: Molecular resolution imaging by post-labeling expansion single-molecule localization microscopy (Ex-SMLM)
authors: Fabian U. Zwettler, Sebastian Reinhard, Davide Gambarotto, Toby D. M. Bell, Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard, Markus Sauer
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the use of pre-labeling Ex-SMLM on microtubules, showing improved resolution. Fig 2: Compares pre-labeling and post-labeling Ex-SMLM, highlighting the reduction in linkage error. Fig 3: Shows 3D post-labeling Ex-SMLM on microtubules, achieving high spatial resolution. Fig 4: Applies Ex-SMLM to centrioles, revealing detailed ultrastructural organization.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of ultrastructural details of microtubules and centrioles with molecular resolution, overcoming previous limitations in labeling efficiency and linkage error.
novelty: This study introduces a post-labeling Ex-SMLM approach that significantly reduces linkage error and improves labeling efficiency compared to previous ExM variants. The re-embedding strategy allows the use of standard photoswitching buffers, enabling dSTORM imaging of expanded samples with sub-10-nm resolution, bridging the gap to electron microscopy.

title: Spatially resolved proteomics via tissue expansion
authors: Lu Li, Cuiji Sun, Yaoting Sun, Zhen Dong, Runxin Wu, Xiaoting Sun, Hanbin Zhang, Wenhao Jiang, Yan Zhou, Xufeng Cen, Shang Cai, Hongguang Xia, Yi Zhu, Tiannan Guo, Kiryl D. Piatkevich
summary: Fig 1: Developed ProteomEx workflow for spatially resolved proteomics using tissue expansion and manual microdissection. Fig 2: Benchmarked ProteomEx against traditional methods, showing higher peptide yield and lower missed cleavages. Fig 3: Validated ProteomEx in different tissues, demonstrating isotropic expansion and high protein identification. Fig 4: Applied ProteomEx to AD mouse brains, identifying differentially expressed proteins in specific brain subregions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the mapping of proteome heterogeneity in mammalian tissues with high spatial resolution, allowing for the identification of proteins associated with Alzheimer's disease in specific brain subregions.
novelty: ProteomEx offers a higher expansion factor and spatial resolution compared to previous methods like proExM-MS, enabling detailed proteomic analysis of sub-nanoliter tissue volumes. The use of N-succinimidyl acrylate for protein anchoring provides better chemical stability and accessibility, making the method more user-friendly and applicable to various tissue types.

title: iU-ExM: nanoscopy of organelles and tissues with iterative ultrastructure expansion microscopy
authors: Vincent Louvel, Romuald Haase, Olivier Mercey, Marine H. Laporte, Thibaut Eloy, Étienne Baudrier, Denis Fortun, Dominique Soldati-Favre, Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard
summary: Fig 1: iU-ExM development shows improved expansion and staining conditions, achieving 16x expansion. Fig 2: iU-ExM reveals 8-fold symmetry of nuclear pores, comparable to SMLM resolution. Fig 3: iU-ExM visualizes Toxoplasma gondii conoid structure, resolving tubulin fibers. Fig 4: iU-ExM applied to membranous organelles, showing mitochondria and ER structure. Fig 5: iU-ExM on mouse retina reveals ciliary periodicity, demonstrating compatibility with tissue imaging.
application_goal: The iU-ExM protocol enables visualization of molecular details with a resolution comparable to SMLM, using conventional fluorescence microscopy. It allows for the study of subcellular organization and molecular architecture in a broader range of laboratories without specialized equipment.
novelty: iU-ExM combines U-ExM with iterative expansion to achieve SMLM-level resolution, surpassing previous ExM variants. The method optimizes homogenization and staining, achieving a 16x expansion factor. It reveals molecular details in organelles and tissues, offering a resolution better than 20 nm, which is a significant improvement over traditional ExM techniques.

title: Trifunctional sphingomyelin derivatives enable nanoscale resolution of sphingomyelin turnover in physiological and infection processes via expansion microscopy
authors: Marcel Rühling, Louise Kersting, Fabienne Wagner, Fabian Schumacher, Dominik Wigger, Dominic A. Helmerich, Tom Pfeuffer, Robin Elflein, Christian Kappe, Markus Sauer, Christoph Arenz, Burkhard Kleuser, Thomas Rudel, Martin Fraunholz, Jürgen Seibel
summary: Fig 1: Design and synthesis of trifunctional sphingomyelin derivatives for click-chemistry and fixation. Fig 2: Metabolic acceptance of TFSMs by human cells and visualization of cellular membranes. Fig 3: TFSMs incorporated in cellular compartments and used to determine bacterial sphingomyelinase activity. Fig 4: TFSMs compatible with expansion microscopy, enabling visualization of cellular membranes at higher resolution. Fig 5: Chlamydia inclusions enriched with metabolized TFSMs, indicating sphingolipid metabolism during infection.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of sphingomyelin turnover and metabolism in cells at nanoscale resolution, providing insights into sphingolipid distribution during physiological and infection processes.
novelty: This study introduces trifunctional sphingomyelin derivatives that allow for nanoscale resolution imaging of sphingomyelin turnover using expansion microscopy. Unlike previous methods, these derivatives enable visualization of sphingomyelin metabolism in both physiological and infection contexts, offering a new tool for studying lipid dynamics. The combination of click-chemistry and expansion microscopy provides a significant advancement over traditional probes, allowing for detailed analysis of sphingomyelinase activity and sphingolipid distribution in cells.

title: Spatial proteomics of single cells and organelles on tissue slides using filter-aided expansion proteomics
authors: Zhen Dong, Wenhao Jiang, Chunlong Wu, Ting Chen, Jiayi Chen, Xuan Ding, Shu Zheng, Kiryl D. Piatkevich, Yi Zhu, Tiannan Guo
summary: Fig 1: FAXP workflow is introduced, improving sample preparation speed and resolution. Fig 2: Optimization of tissue expansion and anchoring conditions enhances expansion uniformity. Fig 3: Comparison of in-gel and in-tip digestion shows improved peptide and protein identifications with in-tip method. Fig 4: FAXP achieves high spatial resolution and sensitivity, enabling single-nucleus proteomics. Fig 5: Application of FAXP to colorectal cancer samples reveals intra-tissue variability and potential biomarkers.
application_goal: The FAXP protocol enabled high-resolution spatial proteomics of FFPE tissue samples, allowing for detailed analysis of protein expression at the single-cell and subcellular levels. This approach facilitated the study of intra-tissue variability in colorectal cancer, providing insights into disease progression and potential therapeutic targets.
novelty: FAXP represents a significant advancement over previous expansion proteomics methods like ProteomEx by offering improved spatial resolution and sample processing speed. The integration of filter-aided in-gel digestion enhances proteome coverage and reproducibility. Unlike traditional LCM, FAXP allows for the analysis of single nuclei, expanding the capabilities of spatial proteomics to subcellular structures. This method is particularly advantageous for archived FFPE samples, making it accessible for clinical research.

title: Rapid lightsheet fluorescence imaging of whole Drosophila brains at nanoscale resolution by potassium acrylate-based expansion microscopy
authors: Xuejiao Tian, Tzu-Yang Lin, Po-Ting Lin, Min-Ju Tsai, Hsin Chen, Wen-Jie Chen, Chia-Ming Lee, Chiao-Hui Tu, Jui-Cheng Hsu, Tung-Han Hsieh, Yi-Chung Tung, Chien-Kai Wang, Suewei Lin, Li-An Chu, Fan-Gang Tseng, Yi-Ping Hsueh, Chi-Hon Lee, Peilin Chen, Bi-Chang Chen
summary: Fig 1: Developed KA-ExM protocol for Drosophila brains, achieving 8x expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrated iterative re-KA-ExM for 13x expansion, maintaining structural integrity. Fig 3: PKA-ExM achieved 10x expansion, visualizing sub-synaptic structures. Fig 4: Iterative re-PKA-ExM reached 32x expansion, enabling detailed 3D mapping. Fig 5: Visualized Tm5a neurons in optic lobe with >40x expansion, revealing dendritic processes. Fig 6: Segmented Tm5a neurons, showing detailed connectivity. Fig 7: Multicolor imaging of L3 neurons and photoreceptors, illustrating synaptic arrangements. Fig 8: Mapped mitochondria and Bruchpilot proteins, highlighting nanoscale organization.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of whole Drosophila brains, allowing visualization of neuronal structures and synaptic components at nanoscale resolution, comparable to electron microscopy.
novelty: This study introduces potassium acrylate-based expansion microscopy (KA-ExM) and its iterative variant (re-KA-ExM), achieving unprecedented expansion ratios of up to 40x. The use of potassium acrylate and polyacrylate provides enhanced mechanical strength and stability, allowing for the imaging of large, intact samples such as whole Drosophila brains. This approach surpasses previous ExM methods by enabling detailed visualization of neuronal circuits and synaptic structures, bridging the gap between light microscopy and electron microscopy in terms of resolution and sample size.

title: Dense, continuous membrane labeling and expansion microscopy visualization of ultrastructure in tissues
authors: Tay Won Shin, Hao Wang, Chi Zhang, Bobae An, Yangning Lu, Elizabeth Zhang, Xiaotang Lu, Emmanouil D. Karagiannis, Jeong Seuk Kang, Amauche Emenari, Panagiotis Symvoulidis, Shoh Asano, Leanne Lin, Emma K. Costa, IMAXT Grand Challenge Consortium, Adam H. Marblestone, Narayanan Kasthuri, Li-Huei Tsai, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: umExM protocol was developed for dense membrane labeling in tissues, enabling nanoscale visualization. Fig 2: umExM achieved ~60 nm resolution, validated by Fourier Ring Correlation analysis. Fig 3: umExM visualized neuronal processes in mouse brain, supporting segmentation and tracing. Fig 4: umExM combined with antibody staining and FISH for protein and RNA visualization. Fig 5: umExM enabled segmentation of neuronal compartments, facilitating analysis of signaling proteins. Fig 6: umExM supported manual tracing of axons, demonstrating its utility in neuronal mapping.
application_goal: The protocol enabled dense labeling of membranes in tissues, allowing for nanoscale visualization of membranous structures and facilitating the segmentation and tracing of neuronal processes in mouse brain tissue.
novelty: umExM introduces a novel membrane labeling probe and optimized expansion microscopy protocol, achieving dense and continuous membrane labeling with high signal-to-background ratio. Compared to previous ExM variants, umExM provides improved resolution (~60 nm) and supports co-visualization of membranes, proteins, and RNAs. The iterative expansion strategy further enhances resolution to ~35 nm, approaching electron microscopy levels on a standard confocal microscope.

title: Single extracellular vesicle imaging via rolling circle amplification–expansion microscopy
authors: Jiacheng Wu, Quanhao Dou, Miao Mao, Xin Wan, Minhao Wu, Tony Y. Hu, Yuanqing Zhang
summary: Fig 1: The RCA–ExM method integrates rolling circle amplification with expansion microscopy to profile single EVs, enhancing diagnostic capabilities. Fig 2: A dual-labeling approach captures and labels tumor-derived EVs, improving specificity and sensitivity. Fig 3: Liposome fusion delivers an enzyme circuit for miRNA detection, amplifying signal for precise analysis. Fig 4: RCA–ExM enables super-resolution imaging of single EVs, distinguishing multiple phenotypes. Fig 5: The method differentiates cancer patients and predicts immunotherapy efficacy, showcasing its clinical potential.
application_goal: The protocol enables the sensitive and specific detection of single extracellular vesicles (EVs) by integrating rolling circle amplification with expansion microscopy. This approach allows for the profiling of EVs at the single-particle level, providing detailed insights into their molecular heterogeneity and potential as biomarkers for cancer diagnosis and treatment monitoring.
novelty: This study introduces a novel integration of rolling circle amplification with expansion microscopy (RCA–ExM) to achieve super-resolution imaging of single extracellular vesicles (EVs). Unlike previous methods, RCA–ExM allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple biomolecules, including proteins and miRNAs, on individual EVs using conventional fluorescence microscopy. The method's ability to distinguish cancer patients and predict immunotherapy efficacy highlights its potential for clinical applications. The use of liposome fusion for miRNA detection and the streamlined workflow for EV capture and labeling represent significant advancements over existing techniques.

title: A basal body microtubule singlet-to-doublet transition in Plasmodium male gametogenesis
authors: Shuzhen Yang, Shanshan Ma, Chengxian Yuan, Zhixun Li, Fanbiao Ji, Luming Yao, Huiting Cui, Qiang Guo, Jing Yuan
summary: Fig 1: iU-ExM and TEM reveal MT singlet-to-doublet transition in P. yoelii basal body, distinct from canonical triplet-to-doublet. Fig 2: Cryo-ET shows polarized funnel shape of BB with asynchronous B-tubule assembly. Fig 3: δ-Tubulin localizes at BB, essential for axoneme formation. Fig 4: δ-Tub and ε-Tub are crucial for male gametogenesis and mosquito transmission. Fig 5: δ-Tub and ε-Tub regulate axoneme assembly, with defects in mutants. Fig 6: δ-Tub localizes at B-tubule proximal end, suggesting role in B-tubule assembly.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of the native microtubule organization in the basal body of Plasmodium male gametes, revealing a unique singlet-to-doublet transition pattern. This insight is crucial for understanding the axonemal assembly process in Plasmodium, which differs from the canonical triplet-to-doublet transition observed in other eukaryotes.
novelty: This study introduces a novel insight into the microtubule organization within the basal body of Plasmodium male gametes, highlighting a singlet-to-doublet transition rather than the canonical triplet-to-doublet transition. The use of iU-ExM combined with cryo-ET provides unprecedented resolution, allowing for the detailed observation of δ-Tubulin and ε-Tubulin's roles in axoneme formation. This work contrasts with previous studies by demonstrating the unique structural adaptations in Plasmodium, which may facilitate rapid gametogenesis and transmission.

title: Expansion microscopy applied to mono- and dual-species biofilms
authors: David Valdivieso González, Josué Jara, Víctor G. Almendro-Vedia, Belén Orgaz, Iván López-Montero
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the workflow for biofilm expansion microscopy, highlighting the enzymatic digestion and expansion process. Fig 2: Shows the preservation of bacterial morphology and biofilm architecture post-expansion, compared with SEM images. Fig 3: Quantifies the isotropic expansion factor across different bacterial species. Fig 4: Validates the preservation of the three-dimensional structure of biofilms post-expansion. Fig 5: Confirms nanoscale resolution by measuring the division septum in S. aureus. Fig 6: Illustrates the structural integrity of dual-species biofilms post-expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of the three-dimensional architecture of biofilms, preserving the morphology and spatial distribution of bacterial species within the extracellular matrix. This advancement allows for a better understanding of biofilm structure and interactions, which is crucial for developing strategies to prevent and treat biofilm-associated infections.
novelty: This study optimizes existing ExM protocols for application to bacterial biofilms, particularly mono- and dual-species biofilms. The use of a combined enzymatic digestion step with lysozyme and mutanolysin is highlighted as a key improvement, allowing for isotropic expansion of biofilms. Compared to previous ExM variants, this approach successfully maintains the structural integrity of biofilms, including the extracellular matrix, which is a significant advancement in the study of complex microbial communities.

title: Light-microscopy-based connectomic reconstruction of mammalian brain tissue
authors: Mojtaba R. Tavakoli, Julia Lyudchik, Michał Januszewski, Vitali Vistunou, Nathalie Agudelo Dueñas, Jakob Vorlaufer, Christoph Sommer, Caroline Kreuzinger, Bárbara Oliveira, Alban Cenameri, Gaia Novarino, Viren Jain, Johann G. Danzl

anchoring.reagent: N-acryloxysuccinimide (NAS), glycidyl methacrylate (GMA), glycerol triglycidyl ether (TGE)

summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the LICONN technology for dense reconstruction of brain circuitry at synaptic resolution. Fig 2: Shows automated segmentation using flood-filling networks for accurate neuronal structure reconstruction. Fig 3: Illustrates molecular labelling and synapse detection using immunolabelling for synaptic proteins. Fig 4: Describes connectivity analysis and deep-learning-based synapse detection, mapping synaptic input fields. Fig 5: Explores applications of LICONN beyond synaptic connectivity, including cell type identification and subcellular structure characterization.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the dense reconstruction of brain circuitry with light microscopy at synaptic resolution, integrating molecular information into synapse-level reconstructions of brain tissue.
novelty: LICONN offers a unique combination of high-fidelity iterative hydrogel expansion and protein-density staining, enabling synapse-level phenotyping of brain tissue. Unlike previous ExM variants, LICONN achieves effective resolutions of 20-50 nm, allowing for detailed volumetric annotation and automated segmentation with accuracy comparable to state-of-the-art EM results. The method provides direct and simultaneous measurement of spatially resolved molecular information, including specific proteins that reveal chemical synapse subtypes, electrical synapses, and key subcellular features.

title: Imaging brain tissue architecture across millimeter to nanometer scales
authors: Julia M. Michalska, Julia Lyudchik, Philipp Velicky, Hana Štefaničková, Jake F. Watson, Alban Cenameri, Christoph Sommer, Nicole Amberg, Alessandro Venturino, Karl Roessler, Thomas Czech, Romana Höftberger, Sandra Siegert, Gaia Novarino, Peter Jonas, Johann G. Danzl
summary: Fig 1: CATS platform developed for mapping brain tissue architecture from millimeter to nanometer scales, using extracellular labeling and optical imaging. Fig 2: Automated pipeline for mapping putative synaptic cleft regions (pSCRs) using deep learning and super-resolution imaging. Fig 3: Integration of structural and functional information in organotypic hippocampal slices, revealing synaptic inputs of characterized neurons. Fig 4: Characterization of synaptic output field of a DG granule cell, showing complex synaptic connections. Fig 5: Application of CATS in fixed tissue and combination with expansion microscopy for large-scale tissue analysis.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed mapping of brain tissue architecture, allowing for the visualization and quantification of synaptic connectivity and subcellular morphology in both rodent and human samples. It provided a comprehensive view of cellular structures and their molecular context, facilitating the study of brain tissue in health and disease.
novelty: This work introduces the Comprehensive Analysis of Tissues across Scales (CATS) platform, which integrates extracellular labeling with super-resolution imaging to map brain tissue architecture at unprecedented detail. Unlike previous methods, CATS provides a dense, unbiased visualization of cellular structures across scales, from regional to synaptic levels. The study demonstrates the applicability of CATS to both live and fixed tissues, including human clinical specimens, and highlights its potential for high-throughput, large-scale tissue analysis. The combination with expansion microscopy further enhances resolution and allows for extensive volumetric imaging.

title: One-step nanoscale expansion microscopy reveals individual protein shapes
authors: Ali H. Shaib, Abed Alrahman Chouaib, Rajdeep Chowdhury, Jonas Altendorf, Daniel Mihaylov, Chi Zhang, Donatus Krah, Vanessa Imani, Russell K. W. Spencer, Svilen Veselinov Georgiev, Nikolaos Mougios, Mehar Monga, Sofiia Reshetniak, Tiago Mimoso, Han Chen, Parisa Fatehbasharzad, Dagmar Crzan, Kim-Ann Saal, Mohamad Mahdi Alawieh, Nadia Alawar, Janna Eilts, Jinyoung Kang, Alireza Soleimani, Marcus Müller, Constantin Pape, Luis Alvarez, Claudia Trenkwalder, Brit Mollenhauer, Tiago F. Outeiro, Sarah Köster, Julia Preobraschenski, Ute Becherer, Tobias Moser, Edward S. Boyden, A. Radu Aricescu, Markus Sauer, Felipe Opazo, Silvio O. Rizzoli
summary: Fig 1: ONE microscopy was developed to visualize protein shapes with near 1-nm resolution, using a combination of X10 expansion and SRRF. Fig 2: The technique was applied to visualize immunoglobulins and otoferlin, revealing their expected structures. Fig 3: 3D reconstructions of GABAARs were achieved, showing consistency with known structures. Fig 4: ONE microscopy was used to detect α-synuclein oligomers in cerebrospinal fluid, distinguishing Parkinson's disease samples from controls.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of individual protein shapes at near 1-nm resolution, bridging the gap between high-resolution structural biology techniques and conventional light microscopy. This allows for the analysis of protein conformational changes and the morphology of protein aggregates in clinical samples, potentially aiding in disease diagnosis.
novelty: This study introduces ONE microscopy, a novel expansion microscopy technique that achieves near 1-nm resolution by combining X10 expansion with SRRF. Unlike previous ExM variants, ONE microscopy allows for the visualization of individual protein shapes without the need for super-resolution optics. The use of DMAA as a monomer and Acryloyl-X for anchoring provides a more homogeneous expansion, reducing errors. This approach enables the study of small proteins and protein complexes that were previously inaccessible to fluorescence microscopy.

title: GelMap: intrinsic calibration and deformation mapping for expansion microscopy
authors: Hugo G. J. Damstra, Josiah B. Passmore, Albert K. Serweta, Ioannis Koutlas, Mithila Burute, Frank J. Meye, Anna Akhmanova, Lukas C. Kapitein
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrated pattern transfer from substrate to hydrogel using TREx, highlighting deformation correction. Fig 2: Validated GelMap's correction of cellular deformations using pre- and post-expansion imaging. Fig 3: Showcased GelMap's utility in correlative live-cell and expansion microscopy, aiding sample navigation. Fig 4: Applied GelMap to tissue slices, enabling correction of local deformations and visualization of synaptic structures.
application_goal: The protocol enabled precise determination of local expansion factors and correction of deformations in expanded samples, facilitating quantitative and diagnostic applications of expansion microscopy.
novelty: GelMap introduces a scalable fluorescent grid for intrinsic calibration of ExM hydrogels, allowing for precise local expansion factor determination and deformation correction without pre-expansion imaging. This method enhances the accuracy and reproducibility of ExM, particularly in high-expansion scenarios, and is compatible with various ExM variants like TREx and pan-ExM. GelMap's integration into existing workflows provides a robust quality control step, addressing limitations of previous ExM methods that lacked easy-to-use reference-free quality control mechanisms.

title: TEMI: tissue-expansion mass-spectrometry imaging
authors: Hua Zhang, Lang Ding, Amy Hu, Xudong Shi, Penghsuan Huang, Haiyan Lu, Paul W. Tillberg, Meng C. Wang, Lingjun Li
summary: Fig 1: TEMI was used to map lipid distribution across cerebellar layers, revealing spatial biomolecular heterogeneity. Fig 2: Single-cell-resolution TEMI mapping of Purkinje cells showed specific lipid enrichment. Fig 3: TEMI mapped small metabolites in cerebellum, highlighting spatial metabolic heterogeneity. Fig 4: TEMI imaged proteins and N-glycans, revealing distinctive distributions. Fig 5: TEMI revealed metabolic heterogeneity in mouse tumors, segmenting tissue into more regions than unexpanded samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution spatial mapping of biomolecules in tissues, revealing metabolic heterogeneity and structural organization in cerebellum and tumors, and was applicable to other organs like kidney and pancreas.
novelty: TEMI offers a non-denaturing, iterative expansion method that preserves biomolecules for high-resolution MSI, unlike previous methods that used harsh treatments. It achieves single-cell resolution and reveals biomolecular heterogeneity without signal loss or delocalization, setting it apart from prior ExM variants.

title: Expansion and fluctuations-enhanced microscopy for nanoscale molecular profiling of cells and tissues
authors: Dominik Kylies, Hannah S. Heil, Arturo G. Vesga, Mario Del Rosario, Maria Schwerk, Malte Kuehl, Milagros N. Wong, Victor G. Puelles, Ricardo Henriques
summary: Fig 1: Overview of the ExSRRF workflow, highlighting molecular labeling, expansion, and eSRRF imaging. Fig 2: Demonstrates the resolution enhancement achieved with ExSRRF compared to conventional microscopy. Fig 3: Shows parameter optimization for eSRRF processing to achieve optimal image quality. Fig 4: Illustrates the use of quantitative metrics to assess image fidelity and resolution improvements.
application_goal: The protocol enables nanoscale profiling of biological specimens using conventional microscopes by combining expansion microscopy with enhanced super-resolution radial fluctuations analysis, allowing for detailed investigation of cellular ultrastructure and protein localization.
novelty: This work introduces a novel combination of expansion microscopy with enhanced super-resolution radial fluctuations (ExSRRF), achieving 25 nm resolution using conventional microscopes. Compared to previous ExM variants, ExSRRF offers improved accessibility and flexibility without the need for specialized equipment. The integration of eSRRF provides enhanced image fidelity and resolution, extending the applicability of ExM to a broader range of biological and clinical samples.

title: Protein and lipid expansion microscopy with trypsin and tyramide signal amplification for 3D imaging
authors: Ueh-Ting Tim Wang, Xuejiao Tian, Yae-Huei Liou, Sue-Ping Lee, Hsiao-Tang Hu, Chieh-Han Lu, Po-Ting Lin, Ya-Jen Cheng, Peilin Chen, Bi-Chang Chen
summary: Fig 1: TT-ExM protocol is introduced, highlighting trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification to enhance fluorescence signals. Fig 2: Demonstrates enhanced protein retention and imaging of endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria in COS-7 cells. Fig 3: Comparison of trypsin and proteinase K digestion shows better fluorophore retention with trypsin. Fig 4: Quantitative analysis of expansion ratio and isotropicity in TT-ExM. Fig 5: Biotin-DHPE staining reveals complex lipid structures in COS-7 cells. Fig 6: TT-ExM applied to cultured neurons shows clear mitochondrial morphology. Fig 7: Nuclear structures in neurons are visualized, revealing lipid-rich compartments.
application_goal: The protocol enables enhanced fluorescence signal retention and visualization of protein and lipid structures in 3D, using readily available reagents, making it accessible for general biological laboratories.
novelty: TT-ExM introduces a novel combination of trypsin digestion and tyramide signal amplification, improving fluorophore retention and signal intensity compared to traditional ExM methods. This approach simplifies the protocol by using common reagents and enhances resolution to 63 nm, making it suitable for detailed imaging of cellular structures. Unlike previous ExM variants, TT-ExM effectively visualizes lipid-rich structures, expanding its applicability to diverse biological samples.

title: Subdiffraction-resolution fluorescence imaging of immunological synapse formation between NK cells and A. fumigatus by expansion microscopy
authors: Nora Trinks, Sebastian Reinhard, Matthias Drobny, Linda Heilig, Jürgen Löffler, Markus Sauer, Ulrich Terpitz
summary: Fig 1: Developed a protocol for simultaneous expansion of NK cells and fungi, enabling detailed visualization of immunological synapse formation. Fig 2: Demonstrated cytoskeleton rearrangement in NK cells upon interaction with A. fumigatus, highlighting MTOC migration. Fig 3: Visualized lytic granules, showing colocalization of perforin and granulysin, with perforin appearing in a ring-like structure. Fig 4: Assessed NK-cell degranulation, showing surface LAMP1 exposure and perforin reduction post-degranulation. Fig 5: Used ExM to reveal perforin surrounded by LAMP1, indicating polarized degranulation.
application_goal: The protocol enabled simultaneous expansion and imaging of NK cells and A. fumigatus hyphae, allowing for unprecedented spatial resolution in studying immunological synapse formation and cytoskeletal rearrangements during NK cell-fungus interactions.
novelty: This study introduces a refined ExM protocol for simultaneous expansion of mammalian and fungal cells, achieving unmatched spatial resolution in visualizing NK cell interactions with A. fumigatus. Unlike previous ExM variants, this approach allows for detailed analysis of immune cell-fungus interactions, revealing new insights into cytoskeletal dynamics and degranulation processes. The study highlights the potential of ExM to resolve cellular structures beyond the capabilities of traditional super-resolution methods, offering a new tool for studying complex biological interactions.

title: 3D-Aligner: advanced computational tool for correcting image distortion in expansion microscopy
authors: Jonathan Loi, Dhaval Ghone, Xiaofei Qu, Aussie Suzuki
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the workflow of 3D-Aligner, highlighting its ability to correct drift in ExM images. Fig 2 shows the precision of drift determination in 12-fold expanded RPE1 cells. Fig 3 illustrates the effectiveness of 3D-Aligner in correcting drift in both 4-fold and 12-fold expanded images. Fig 4 quantifies the impact of drift correction on biological structures, showing significant improvements in size and volume measurements post-correction.
application_goal: The protocol enabled precise correction of sample drift in ExM images, allowing for accurate 3D image reconstruction and downstream quantitative analyses of biological structures.
novelty: 3D-Aligner offers a computational solution to the persistent problem of sample drift in ExM, outperforming existing software by providing superior drift correction quality. Unlike previous methods, it uses a nearest-neighbor algorithm for feature matching, ensuring unbiased correction without relying on biological structures. This advancement is crucial for accurate quantification in ExM, especially in high-expansion scenarios like 12-fold ExM.

Fig 2 compares microtubule labeling with secondary antibodies and nanobodies, highlighting reduced linkage error with nanobodies. Fig 4 addresses challenges in in vitro microtubule stabilization, presenting a protocol for preserving microtubules for ExM analysis.
application_goal: The protocol enables the use of microtubules as nanorulers for validating expansion microscopy techniques, providing a reliable standard for assessing resolution and imaging precision.
novelty: This study introduces a protocol for using microtubules as reference standards in ExM, addressing challenges in fluorophore placement and microtubule stabilization. title: Feature-rich covalent stains for super-resolution and cleared tissue fluorescence microscopy
authors: Chenyi Mao, Min Yen Lee, Jing-Ru Jhan, Aaron R. Halpern, Marcus A. Woodworth, Adam K. Glaser, Tyler J. Chozinski, Leonard Shin, Jeffrey W. Pippin, Stuart J. Shankland, Jonathan T.C. Liu, Joshua C. Vaughan
sample: cultured human retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells

model_system: cultured human retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells

summary: Fig 1 illustrates the FLARE staining process for amines and carbohydrates, highlighting its application in super-resolution and cleared tissue microscopy. Fig 2 demonstrates FLARE staining of hydrogel-expanded RPE cells, revealing subcellular structures like mitochondria and lysosomes. Fig 3 shows FLARE staining in hydrogel-expanded mouse kidney tissue, highlighting glomeruli and proximal convoluted tubules. Fig 4 compares stain uniformity in thick tissue sections, showing improved results with FLARE over traditional methods. Fig 5 extends FLARE's application to various tissues, including mouse intestine and human prostate, demonstrating its versatility.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the use of commercially available small-molecule fluorophores for covalent labeling of proteins and carbohydrates, providing a robust and simple method for staining a wide variety of organelles and structures in cells and tissues. This approach allows for detailed visualization of biological samples under different fixation and processing conditions, enhancing the capabilities of super-resolution and cleared tissue microscopy.
novelty: This work introduces FLARE, a method that uses covalent stains for proteins and carbohydrates, offering an alternative to traditional antibody-based labeling. Compared to prior ExM variants, FLARE provides a simpler and more robust staining process that is compatible with a wide range of sample processing techniques. The method achieves a resolution of ~65 nm, which is a significant improvement over traditional light microscopy. The use of covalent stains also addresses limitations of antibody labeling, such as poor penetration in thick tissues and inconsistent reproducibility.

authors: Joha Park, Sarim Khan, Dae Hee Yun, Taeyun Ku, Katherine L. Villa, Jiachen E. Lee, Qiangge Zhang, Juhyuk Park, Guoping Feng, Elly Nedivi, Kwanghun Chung
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the preservation of antigenicity in eMAP by avoiding chemical crosslinking, enhancing antibody compatibility. Fig 2 shows the high expansion factor achieved with eMAP, allowing detailed visualization of synaptic proteins. Fig 3 illustrates the multiplexed staining capability of eMAP, enabling detailed proteomic analysis of synapses. Fig 4 highlights the high-throughput potential of eMAP for ultrastructural analysis of synapses using conventional microscopy.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed visualization and analysis of synaptic proteins in expanded brain tissues, allowing for multiplexed staining and high-throughput imaging using conventional microscopy.
novelty: eMAP introduces a purely physical hydrogel-tissue hybridization method that maximizes epitope preservation, contrasting with previous methods that rely on chemical crosslinking. This approach enhances antibody compatibility and signal quality, enabling high-resolution imaging without signal amplification. The iterative expansion strategy achieves up to 10x linear expansion, providing a significant resolution gain over traditional ExM techniques.

summary: The paper discusses the thermodynamic cycles in CESM and MERRA, highlighting the differences in power requirements for maintaining the hydrological cycle. It suggests that CESM's idealized convection schemes might influence its response to anthropogenic forcing. The study identifies a major constraint on the global atmospheric engine, suggesting that as the climate warms, the system may struggle to increase entropy production to offset moistening inefficiencies. This could result in fewer but more energetic storms in a future climate.
application_goal: The protocol enables a better understanding of the constraints on the global atmospheric engine and the potential impacts of climate warming on atmospheric circulation and storm patterns.
novelty: The work provides insights into the constraints on work output in CESM and the implications for global atmospheric circulation under climate change, highlighting the role of moistening inefficiencies and phase transitions.

title: Chromatin expansion microscopy reveals nanoscale organization of transcription and chromatin
authors: Mark E. Pownall, Liyun Miao, Charles E. Vejnar, Ons M’Saad, Alice Sherrard, Megan A. Frederick, Maria D. J. Benitez, Curtis W. Boswell, Kenneth S. Zaret, Joerg Bewersdorf, Antonio J. Giraldez
resolution: 15-nm lateral resolution on a confocal microscope and ~3 nm in STED
summary: Fig 1: ChromExM visualizes Nanog and miR-430 transcription in zebrafish embryos, revealing Nanog's role in transcriptional activation. Fig 2: ChromExM achieves single-nucleosome resolution, preserving chromatin organization and demonstrating isotropic expansion. Fig 3: ChromExM shows Nanog and Pol II organization, identifying distinct classes of transcriptional structures. Fig 4: Inhibition of transcription elongation alters Pol II organization, supporting the 'kiss and kick' model of enhancer-promoter interaction.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of nanoscale chromatin organization and transcriptional processes in vivo, providing insights into the molecular interactions during zygotic genome activation.
novelty: ChromExM offers a significant advancement over previous ExM and super-resolution methods by achieving single-nucleosome resolution and preserving chromatin organization across scales. The study introduces a new model of enhancer-promoter interaction, termed 'kiss and kick', highlighting the dynamic nature of transcriptional regulation. This work surpasses prior ExM variants by combining high-resolution imaging with multimodal labeling, allowing detailed analysis of chromatin and transcription factor interactions.

title: Stimuli-Responsive Phosphate Hydrogel: A Study on Swelling Behavior, Mechanical Properties, and Application in Expansion Microscopy
authors: Yokly Leng, Collin N. Britten, Fatema Tarannum, Kayla Foley, Christopher Billings, Yingtao Liu, Keisha B. Walters
summary: Fig 1 illustrates the chemical structures of MOEP, BMOEP, and PMOEP. Fig 2 shows ESEM images of the hydrogel's porous structure, crucial for drug delivery. Fig 3 presents the deswelling rate in various salt solutions, highlighting divalent cations' impact. Fig 4 uses EDS mapping to confirm calcium presence in the hydrogel. Fig 5 compares swelling rates in different salt concentrations, showing monovalent cations induce more swelling. Fig 6 examines pH effects on swelling, with neutral pH showing significant changes. Fig 7 and 8 explore temperature and polymerization conditions, revealing decreased swelling with increased temperature and pH. Fig 9-11 detail mechanical properties and cytotoxicity, showing PMOEP's potential in biomedical applications. Fig 12 demonstrates PMOEP's application in expansion microscopy, achieving twofold cell expansion.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the synthesis of PMOEP hydrogels with tunable swelling properties, low cytotoxicity, and mechanical robustness, making them suitable for applications in drug delivery, tissue engineering, and expansion microscopy. The study demonstrated the hydrogels' ability to expand biological samples, enhancing imaging resolution and providing insights into cellular structures.
novelty: This work introduces a novel phosphate-based hydrogel synthesized via ARGET-ATRP, offering a unique combination of stimuli-responsive swelling behavior and mechanical properties. Compared to previous ExM variants, PMOEP hydrogels provide enhanced biocompatibility and a twofold expansion factor, surpassing traditional hydrogels in biomedical applications. The study highlights the hydrogel's potential in overcoming the diffraction limit in microscopy, achieving ∼65 nm resolution, and expanding the scope of ExM techniques.

title: Super-Resolution Three-Dimensional Imaging of Actin Filaments in Cultured Cells and the Brain via Expansion Microscopy
authors: Chan E Park, Youngbin Cho, In Cho, Hyunsu Jung, Byeongyeon Kim, Jennifer H. Shin, Sungyoung Choi, Seok-Kyu Kwon, Young Ki Hahn, Jae-Byum Chang
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExM imaging of actin filaments in BS-C-1 cells, showing the retention of actin structures post-expansion. Fig 2 validates the ExM method by comparing actin filament structures with previous super-resolution studies. Fig 3 explores the 3-D organization of actin in overlapping cells, revealing stress fibers and actin invaginations. Fig 4 applies ExM to mouse brain slices, identifying actin structures in the CA1 region. Fig 5 extends the method to multiplex imaging, visualizing actin alongside synaptic proteins in the mouse brain, highlighting the diverse actin organizations in synapses.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-throughput, super-resolution imaging of actin filaments in both cultured cells and thick tissue slices, providing insights into the nanoscale organization of actin in various biological contexts, including synaptic structures in the brain.
novelty: This study introduces a simple labeling process using anti-fluorophore antibodies to achieve ExM imaging of actin filaments, overcoming limitations of previous methods that required custom conjugation. The approach allows for multiplexed imaging of actin and other proteins, providing a resolution of 60 nm, which is a significant improvement over traditional diffraction-limited microscopy. Compared to prior ExM variants, this method offers a straightforward and accessible protocol for typical biology laboratories, enabling detailed visualization of actin structures in complex tissues like the brain.

title: Toward High Spatially Resolved Proteomics Using Expansion Microscopy
authors: Lauranne Drelich, Soulaimane Aboulouard, Julien Franck, Michel Salzet, Isabelle Fournier, Maxence Wisztorski
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the workflow for spatially resolved proteomics using tissue expansion, highlighting the ease of selecting regions of interest for proteomics. Figure 2 compares different homogenization agents, showing SDS as the most effective for protein retention. Figure 3 evaluates reproducibility, indicating consistent protein identification across replicates. Figure 4 uses a biopsy punch to improve sampling precision, enhancing reproducibility. Figure 5 presents quantification-based mass spectrometry profiling, mapping protein distribution across brain regions.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the identification of over 655 proteins from small regions of interest in tissue sections, facilitating spatially resolved proteomics without sophisticated instrumentation.
novelty: This study introduces a novel approach by replacing proteinase K with SDS for homogenization, reducing protein loss and enabling effective protein retention during expansion. Compared to previous methods, this approach allows for the identification of a higher number of proteins from smaller regions, enhancing spatial resolution in proteomics.

title: Trifunctional Linkers Enable Improved Visualization of Actin by Expansion Microscopy
authors: Gang Wen, Matthew Domenic Lycas, Yuqing Jia, Volker Leen, Markus Sauer, Johan Hofkens
summary: Fig 1 illustrates three phalloidin-actin complex anchoring strategies, highlighting the TRITON linker. Fig 2 compares signal retention of TRITON molecules, showing improved retention with multiple acryloyl units. Fig 3 demonstrates optimized TRITON linkers in HeLa cells, achieving high signal retention and resolution. Fig 4 combines ExM with SIM and TREx, enhancing spatial resolution of actin filaments. Fig 5 shows TREx imaging of actin rings in neurons, resolving periodic structures. Fig 6 applies TRITON linkers to mouse brain tissues, visualizing actin filaments with high resolution.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of actin filaments with high spatial resolution using optimized TRITON linkers, improving signal retention and compatibility with multicolor staining in both cellular and tissue samples.
novelty: This study introduces optimized TRITON linkers with multiple acryloyl units, significantly enhancing signal retention and resolution in ExM. Compared to previous ExM variants, the TRITON system allows direct anchoring of phalloidin labels with negligible linkage error, outperforming methods using antifluorophore antibodies or streptavidin. The work demonstrates compatibility with various labeling strategies and multicolor staining, offering a robust tool for actin visualization in diverse biological contexts.

title: Expanding Insights: Harnessing Expansion Microscopy for Super-Resolution Analysis of HIV-1–Cell Interactions
authors: Annett Petrich, Gyu Min Hwang, Laetitia La Rocca, Mariam Hassan, Maria Anders-Össwein, Vera Sonntag-Buck, Anke-Mareil Heuser, Vibor Laketa, Barbara Müller, Hans-Georg Kräusslich, Severina Klaus
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the robust expansion of TZM-bl cells using U-ExM, achieving a 4.3-fold increase in size. Fig 2 shows the optimization of fixation conditions to preserve cytoplasmic integrity, highlighting the importance of buffer choice. Fig 3 illustrates the successful expansion of various cell types, including primary immune cells, with well-preserved nuclear and cytoplasmic structures. Fig 4 focuses on the preservation of nanoscopic structures, such as the nuclear pore complex, after expansion. Fig 5 explores the visualization of nuclear speckles and nucleoli, confirming the preservation of phase-separated nuclear bodies. Fig 6 presents the application of U-ExM to visualize HIV-1 capsid interactions with the nuclear pore and within the nucleus, revealing distinct stages of the viral replication cycle.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization of HIV-1 capsid interactions with the nuclear pore complex and within the nucleus, providing insights into the post-entry stages of the viral replication cycle. This approach allows for the identification and characterization of different stages in the HIV-1 replication cycle with enhanced spatial resolution.
novelty: This study demonstrates the application of U-ExM in virology, particularly for HIV-1 research, by enabling the visualization of viral structures at a resolution that bridges the gap between fluorescence and electron microscopy. Compared to prior ExM variants, U-ExM offers improved labeling efficiency and reduced linkage errors, facilitating the detection of previously masked epitopes. The combination of U-ExM with Airyscan microscopy provides a user-friendly alternative to more technically challenging super-resolution methods like STED and SMLM, allowing for the exploration of virus-host interactions at the nanoscale.

title: Combining single-molecule and expansion microscopy in fission yeast to visualize protein structures at the nanostructural level
authors: Ilijana Vojnovic, Oliver D. Caspari, Mehmet Ali Hoşkan, Ulrike Endesfelder
summary: Fig 1: Demonstrates the SExY protocol achieving fivefold expansion of yeast cells, crucial for visualizing protein structures. Fig 2: Shows optimization of cell wall digestion and protein retention, enhancing isotropic expansion. Fig 3: Illustrates successful imaging of various proteins, highlighting the protocol's applicability to low-abundance targets.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of protein structures in fission yeast at nanostructural levels, particularly benefiting studies targeting low-abundance proteins or those relying on genetic labeling.
novelty: This study introduces a robust ExPALM protocol for fission yeast, achieving higher expansion factors than previous ExM-SRM combinations like ExSTORM. The use of Lallzyme MMX for cell wall digestion and glutathione during gelation are novel optimizations enhancing protein retention and isotropic expansion.

title: iU-ExM: nanoscopy of organelles and tissues with iterative ultrastructure expansion microscopy
authors: Vincent Louvel, Romuald Haase, Olivier Mercey, Marine H. Laporte, Thibaut Eloy, Étienne Baudrier, Denis Fortun, Dominique Soldati-Favre, Virginie Hamel, Paul Guichard
summary: Fig 1: Developed iU-ExM by optimizing homogenization and staining, achieving 16x expansion. Fig 2: Demonstrated 8-fold symmetry of nuclear pores using iU-ExM, comparable to SMLM. Fig 3: Revealed molecular architecture of Toxoplasma conoid, achieving 10-20 nm resolution. Fig 4: Applied iU-ExM to membranous organelles, visualizing mitochondria and ER. Fig 5: Showed iU-ExM compatibility with tissue, revealing ciliary periodicity in mouse retina.
application_goal: The protocol enabled visualization of molecular details in organelles and tissues with a resolution comparable to SMLM, using conventional fluorescence microscopy.
novelty: iU-ExM combines U-ExM with iterative expansion, achieving higher resolution than previous ExM variants. The method improves on pan-ExM by optimizing homogenization and staining, allowing visualization of structures like nuclear pores and Toxoplasma conoid with unprecedented detail. The approach is compatible with various gel chemistries, enabling further expansion and resolution gains.

title: Single-shot 20-fold expansion microscopy
authors: Shiwei Wang, Tay Won Shin, Harley B. Yoder II, Ryan B. McMillan, Hanquan Su, Yixi Liu, Chi Zhang, Kylie S. Leung, Peng Yin, Laura L. Kiessling, Edward S. Boyden
summary: Fig 1: Developed a superabsorbent hydrogel for single-step 20x expansion, achieving <20-nm resolution. Fig 2: Validated 20ExM resolution by visualizing microtubule structures, achieving comparable results to iterative methods. Fig 3: Demonstrated 20ExM's utility in brain tissue by imaging synaptic nanocolumns, showing alignment of RIM1/2 and PSD95 proteins. Additional figures: Explored 20ExM applications in imaging nuclear pore complexes and mitochondria, achieving high resolution and structural detail.
application_goal: The protocol enabled high-resolution imaging of biological samples, such as brain tissue and cell cultures, with a single expansion step, simplifying the process while achieving the resolution of iterative methods.
novelty: 20ExM achieves a 20x expansion in a single step, providing <20-nm resolution comparable to iterative methods like iExM. This work introduces a new hydrogel composition and oxygen-controlled gelation environment, improving reproducibility and expansion factor. The single-shot approach simplifies the process, making high-resolution imaging more accessible without compromising on performance.

title: Magnify is a universal molecular anchoring strategy for expansion microscopy
authors: Aleksandra Klimas, Brendan R. Gallagher, Piyumi Wijesekara, Sinda Fekir, Emma F. DiBernardo, Zhangyu Cheng, Donna B. Stolz, Franca Cambi, Simon C. Watkins, Steven L. Brody, Amjad Horani, Alison L. Barth, Christopher I. Moore, Xi Ren, Yongxin Zhao
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the Magnify protocol's ability to expand tissues up to 11x, achieving high protein retention. Fig 2 validates Magnify across various human tissues, showing effective expansion and imaging. Fig 3 highlights Magnify's capability to visualize proteins, nucleic acids, and lipids in biological specimens. Fig 4 showcases the visualization of endogenous fluorophores with Magnify, preserving fluorescent protein signals. Fig 5 illustrates the combination of Magnify with SOFI to achieve sub-20 nm resolution imaging of cellular structures. Fig 6 explores the application of Magnify–SOFI in visualizing drug-induced changes in cilia structure.
application_goal: The Magnify protocol enables the visualization of nanoscale structures in a wide range of biological specimens without the need for specialized super-resolution imaging systems. It allows for the retention and imaging of proteins, nucleic acids, and lipids, facilitating postexpansion labeling and high-resolution imaging.
novelty: Magnify introduces a new hydrogel chemistry that eliminates the need for a separate anchoring step, allowing for the retention of a broad spectrum of biomolecules. Compared to previous ExM variants, Magnify achieves a higher expansion factor of up to 11x and provides an effective resolution of around 25 nm. The combination with SOFI further enhances resolution to sub-20 nm, surpassing traditional super-resolution methods without requiring specialized equipment.

title: Protein-retention expansion microscopy of cells and tissues labeled using standard fluorescent proteins and antibodies
authors: Paul W Tillberg, Fei Chen, Kiryl D Piatkevich, Yongxin Zhao, Chih-Chieh (Jay) Yu, Brian P English, Linyi Gao, Anthony Martorell, Ho-Jun Suk, Fumiaki Yoshida, Ellen M DeGennaro, Douglas H Roossien, Guanyu Gong, Uthpala Seneviratne, Steven R Tannenbaum, Robert Desimone, Dawen Cai, Edward S Boyden
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the retention of fluorescence signals in proExM-treated cells, showing the method's compatibility with standard fluorescent proteins and antibodies. Fig 2 validates proExM in various mammalian tissues, highlighting its ability to preserve tissue morphology and fluorescence signals post-expansion. Fig 3 applies proExM to visualize brain circuitry in mice and macaques, demonstrating its utility in resolving dendritic spines and neuronal structures. The figures collectively illustrate proExM's potential for high-resolution imaging of complex biological samples.
application_goal: The protocol enabled nanoscale imaging of immunostained cells and tissues, as well as samples expressing various fluorescent proteins, using conventional microscopy setups. This approach allows for the visualization of biological structures with super-resolution precision without the need for specialized equipment.
novelty: proExM introduces a significant advancement over previous ExM variants by enabling the direct anchoring of proteins to a swellable gel using a commercially available cross-linker. This method retains fluorescence signals from genetically encoded proteins and antibodies, overcoming limitations of previous ExM protocols that required custom reagents. The ability to use standard antibodies and fluorescent proteins simplifies the workflow and broadens the applicability of ExM to a wider range of biological samples.

title: Molecular organization of mammalian meiotic chromosome axis revealed by expansion STORM microscopy
authors: Huizhong Xu, Zhisong Tong, Qing Ye, Tengqian Sun, Zhenmin Hong, Lunfeng Zhang, Alexandra Bortnick, Sunglim Cho, Paolo Beuzer, Joshua Axelrod, Qiongzheng Hu, Melissa Wang, Sylvia M. Evans, Cornelis Murre, Li-Fan Lu, Sha Sun, Kevin D. Corbett, Hu Cang
summary: Fig 1 demonstrates the ExSTORM procedure, showing improved resolution and structural preservation in expanded samples. Fig 2 reveals the organization of SYCP2 and SYCP3 in the chromosome axis, with SYCP2 forming a shell around the SYCP3 core. Fig 3 examines the distribution of HORMAD1 and HORMAD2, showing a broader distribution than SYCP3, suggesting a core-shell structure. Fig 4 investigates cohesin complexes, indicating they are located around the axis core, potentially associating with SYCP2.
application_goal: The protocol enabled detailed structural investigation of the meiotic chromosome axis, revealing a core-shell organization of axis proteins and providing insights into the spatial arrangement of cohesin complexes and HORMAD proteins.
novelty: This study combines expansion microscopy with STORM (ExSTORM) to achieve a resolution of 10-20 nm, surpassing previous methods. The work reveals a core-shell organization of meiotic chromosome axis proteins, a structural detail not previously resolved by conventional super-resolution techniques. The use of ExSTORM provides a significant resolution improvement over traditional STORM, offering new insights into chromosome architecture.

title: Zooming in on the Glycome: Visualizing Glycans at the Nanoscale Level through Expansion Microscopy
authors: Joshua M. Kofsky, Chantelle J. Capicciotti
summary: Figure 1 demonstrates the use of expansion microscopy to image glycans at the nanoscale, highlighting its ability to resolve fine ultrastructures. Figure 2 illustrates the metabolic incorporation of azide-containing probes into glycans, enabling their visualization through bioorthogonal click reactions. The study applies this method to cultured breast cancer cells, revealing nanoscale glycan patterns on cell membranes. Additionally, the technique is extended to C. elegans larvae, showing detailed O-glycosylation patterns in both exposed and internal tissues. This work significantly advances the mapping of glycosylation in live and fixed organisms without specialized TEM imaging.
application_goal: The protocol enabled the visualization and mapping of glycans at the nanoscale within cells, tissues, and whole organisms, providing insights into glycan-mediated processes and their roles in health and disease.
novelty: This study introduces a novel expansion microscopy technique that combines metabolic oligosaccharide engineering with trifunctional ExM linkers to image glycans. Unlike previous ExM variants focused on proteins, DNA, and RNA, this method allows for direct imaging of glycans, overcoming challenges in multicellular systems. The approach is compatible with standard protein ExM protocols and offers resolution comparable to electron microscopy, expanding the scope of ExM to include glycans and potentially other biomolecules.
